story: Queen Elizabeth II news: Why does the Queen always carry a handbag?The 92-year-old has been driving since she was 19.The then-Princess Elizabeth learned to drive a car at a training centre in 1945 while working in the wartime Auxiliary Territorial Service.The Queen&rsquos passion for driving has been well documented over the years, with photos capturing her behind the wheel.Protocol dictates she is normally chauffeured, but Queen Elizabeth is said to be determined to drive herself around when possible.Queen Elizabeth II news: Her Majesty has been driving for more than 70 years (Image: )Queen Elizabeth II news: She is said to have a passion for driving (Image: )However, while it would be unlikely to see Her Majesty cruising around the streets of London she is said to often be behind the wheel when out of public view.Not needing a licence to drive is just one of the Queen&rsquos privileges.Along with no driving licence the British Monarch does not need a passport to travel abroad.This is also because Queen Elizabeth is the one to issue them.                Why does the Queen always wear brightly coloured neon outfits?                Queen Elizabeth II news: Why does the Queen always wear gloves?Queen Elizabeth II news: The Queen driving an ambulance during her wartime service  (Image: )The first page of all British passports read: &ldquoHer Britannic Majesty's Secretary of State requests and requires in the name of Her Majesty all those whom it may concern to allow the bearer to pass freely without let or hindrance and to afford the bearer such assistance and protection as may be necessary.Queen Elizabeth has visited more than 100 countries during her reign, but she has not needed to provide any proof of identity once.This is a privilege for the reigning monarch only.Royals including Prince Charles and the Duke of Edinburgh have to hold a passport, the Queen is the only one exempt from the rules.Queen Elizabeth II news: The 92-year-old has been driving since she was 19 (Image: )Other powers the Queen is entitled to include being exempt from FOI (Freedom of Information) requests, being able to fire the whole Australian government and having her own private cash machine and her own personal poet.In addition, she is signing laws, creating lords and forming Governments.She also owns all of the swans in the River Thames, along with any dolphins in British waters.And if that was not enough, Her Majesty gets to celebrate her birthday twice a year.

The idea that the only thing this country should accept is a fudge or the abyss is not only an insult to the intelligence of British voters, it&rsquos simply not true.Reflecting on his time as a European Commission official and former MEP, Sir Nick told the BBC that the EU could be willing to allow the UK a more flexible time-scale in which to negotiate a withdrawal deal.He said that during his decade-long career in Brussels, &ldquonot a single negotiation I was involved in during that ten year period ever ended on time.He said: The clock can definitely be changed&hellip The one thing that is very elastic in Brussels is time. They&rsquove got a name for it, it&rsquos called &lsquostop the clock&rsquo.&ldquoThis is provided for in the EU treaties. In other words, if the United Kingdom were to say, I&rsquom sorry, we&rsquove got a bit stuck here, we need a bit more time to straighten ourselves out to decide what we&rsquoll do next.This weekend, it was revealed that Sir Nick was in talks with an array of ex-politicians and European leaders in an attempt to persuade them to join forces and stop Brexit.Sir Nick has allegedly been in talks with ex-politicians such as Tony Blair and John Major.He told the : &ldquoThe aim of the visits is to persuade EU leaders that British politics has made the option of remaining inside the EU viable.&ldquoMy primary purpose has been to get European politicians just prepared for the possibility that Britain is not capable of delivering a workable Brexit and they may need to be ready for that.&ldquoIt is a question of pressing them to keep open the extension of the article 50 process beyond the March deadline to give UK negotiators more time including to prepare legislation on a people&rsquos vote.

title: brexit news britain eu uk odds remain olivier desbarres
story: Leading market strategist Olivier Desbarres is predicting a possible second referendum and warned there would be major implications for markets and sterling.Mr Desbarres, a former senior economist, rates and foreign exchange strategist at Credit Suisse and Barclays has produced a detailed report looking at the UK&rsquos options and the implications for the financial sector.He said: &ldquoThe odds of the UK remaining in the EU have significantly increased in recent months and are now non-negligible.&ldquoFor starters, the UK and EU could fail to agree on a post-Brexit deal.                Young Brexiteer SUPERBLY explains why second vote would cause 'CHAOS'                Brexiteer Tory tears into Labour MP for demanding second referendumHe continued: &ldquoThe British Government will be reluctant to materially water down the already unpopular proposal which it put forward on 12 July while the EU will be wary of offering a deal which incentivises other member states to leave the EU on better terms and conditions.Mr Desbarres acknowledge the vocal opposition to Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals from both Brexiteers and Remainers and said a majority of MPs could conceivably vote against such a deal.He said: &ldquoAn already weakened Prime Minister and a Conservative Government short of a parliamentary majority could put political survival ahead of ideology and hold a second referendum &ndash a path backed by a majority of British voters and trade unions and by a growing number of MPs across the political spectrum.Mr Desbarres, who correctly forecast the first and second rounds of last year&rsquos French Presidential elections, said: &ldquoThe British Government could therefore seek to reverse its decision to take the UK out of the EU which would in turn have a material impact on UK yields, equities and in particular sterling.The chances of Britain staying in the UK have increased, according to Olivier Desbarres (Image: )Financial strategist Olivier Desbarres (Image: TWITTEROLIVIERDESBARRES)Brexiteers and Remainers hold protests in London (Image: )His report comes as former Tory leader Lord Hague warned the ongoing war between Leavers and Remainers within the party was jeopardising the Government&rsquos ability to deliver Brexit and also raised the chances of a second referendum.Writing in the Daily , Lord Hague said: &ldquoThe only way for a minority government to negotiate and deliver something as momentous and complex as Brexit is to make many compromises and stick together.&ldquoMost Tory MPs agree with that and, whichever side they were on in the referendum, are being pragmatic so that the will of the people is respected and the country still has a centre-Right government rather than a hard-Left Labour one.&ldquoBut they too have other MPs who say they must have their way.                Brexit news: Is infighting among politicians about to destroy Brexit?                Brexiteer BLASTS Sadiq as London Mayor calls for second Brexit vote&ldquoSuch disunity opens up the potential for a terrible chain of events over the next seven months to the 29 March date for leaving the EU.&ldquoThis is that no agreement can be reached that can be passed by the House of Commons and the new year opens with a choice between leaving without a deal or asking to defer the exit date and holding another referendum.

title: Brexit news UK EU Jacob Rees Mogg Lord Adonis Theresa May European Union
story: Jacob Rees-Mogg refused Lord Adonis&rsquo attempts to organise a &ldquoBrexit duel following a row over Britain&rsquos departure from the European Union.The Conservative MP mocked Lord Adonis for wanting to &ldquoduel over Brexit claiming he thought the idea was &ldquosilly.Speaking on LBC, Mr Rees-Mogg said: &ldquoI thought the whole thing was silly.&ldquoThe idea of a duel, I might be old fashioned, but I don&rsquot think duelling brings credit to anybody.                Brexiteer Tory tears into Labour MP for demanding second referendum                Tory MEP confident UK will create BETTER Commonwealth Galileo systemLBC host Nick Ferrari asked whether the Conservative MP was willing to &ldquodebate Lord Adonis.Jacob Rees-Mogg replied: &ldquoI have debated Lord Adonis before.&ldquoI am always happy to debate people and if he wants to&nbspcall&nbspin, which I understand he may be doing this morning.Ferrari added that his team &ldquocan&rsquot seem to find him as they tried to&nbsporganise&nbspa debate.Mr&nbspRees-Mogg said: &ldquoThey seek him here, they seek him there.The Tory Brexit supporter added he would be perfectly happy to debate Lord Adonis.Lord Adonia, a Remain supporter, was furious with Mr&nbspRees-Mogg for his response to a letter the Labour peer sent at the beginning of August.Speaking earlier this month, Lord Adonis said: &ldquoI think Jacob needs to be frank with the British people.&ldquoHe talks all the time about no-deal being preferable to what the Prime Minister is seeking to negotiate and what I want, which is to stay in the EU with a People's Vote. Let him say what no-deal is.Brexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg responded to Lord Adonis who demanded a Brexit duel (Image: LBC&bullSKYNEWS)Lord Adonis then challenged&nbspMr&nbspRees-Mogg to a duel. He said: &ldquoWe should have this out. I'm going back to the 18th century because I always try to meet Jacob on common ground. I have issued a challenge to him for a duel.In the 18th century, these duels were on Putney Heath. I took advice from the Commissioner of the Met Police, who said the best way to have a duel in modern times is on LBC.I'll be in the studio whenever Jacob responds positively.Mr&nbspRees-Mogg has been hugely critical of the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers agreement, which&nbspMrs&nbspMay has vowed to stick by.

title: BBC News UK Weather forecast Simon McCoy Storm Helene 2018
story: BBC News presenter Simon McCoy was mocked by his colleague and BBC Weather forecaster Darren Bett during a discussion over Storm Helene.Storm Helene is expected to crash into Britain on Monday evening bringing winds of up to 60mph.BBC News host Mr McCoy, known for his hilarious on-air interactions, was jokingly mocked as the pair discussed the storm.Mr Bett said: &ldquoIf we go to the UK, there is some cloud looming on our shores. And some tropical air on the way Simon.                'You're not SURE?' HILARIOUS moment McCoy mocks weather predictions The BBC News host stepped in pointing out the weather system heading for Britain was Storm Helene.He said: &ldquoThis is all to do with Helene is it? The other one you were watching last week.The BBC Weather forecaster continued with his forecast before Mr McCoy pointed out that he does &ldquopay attention.Mr Bett responded with a hilarious dig mocking Mr McCoy. He said: &ldquoYes, I know, very good. What do you want?He added: &ldquoThis Helene was across the other side of the Atlantic and hasn&rsquot made landfall yet.&ldquoAs it has moved northwards it has weakened considerably and the clouds have sort of broken up. It has lost a lot of its identity.Despite losing a lot of its power tracking towards the UK, Storm Helene is still expected to bring winds of up to 60mph.Mr Bett said: &ldquoIt means some warm air, it means some stronger winds.BBC News: BBC forecaster Darren Bett mocked Simon McCoy live on-air (Image: BBCNEWS)&ldquoNot really really ridiculously strong winds at all. But it means some rain for some areas too.&ldquoBecause we are drawing in this tropical air it feels like summer for some parts of the UK.Storm Helene was forecast to hit the southwest of England on Monday evening before sweeping across the north of the UK.

title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May Bank of England Jacob Rees Mogg Mark Carney
story: The Bank of England&rsquos Mark Carney has warned about the consequences of a Brexit no-deal claiming the scenario could cause house prices to plummet.Leading Brexit supporter Jacob Rees-Mogg claimed Mr Carney's predictions for Britain leaving the European Union could &ldquonot be taken seriously.Speaking on LBC, the Conservative MP for North East Somerset branded Mr Carney a &ldquowailing banshee for his assessment of Brexit.Mr Rees-Mogg said: &ldquoMy basis for backing Brexit is that it will be an economic benefit.                Tory MEP confident UK will create BETTER Commonwealth Galileo system                Rees-Mogg MOCKS Lord Adonis who challenged him to a 'Brexit duel'&ldquoThe one thing I will be affected by as, of course, everybody would be in the country is house prices.&ldquoThat was suggested by the Governor of the Bank of England who is quite hysterical about Brexit and can&rsquot be taken seriously.Mr Rees-Mogg said: &ldquoHe is a political apparatchik and has taken the governorship of the Bank of England from one where the odd movement of the eyebrows was influencing markets to one where he is a wailing banshee.&ldquoI don't think it's at all distinguished.Bank of England governor Mr Carney warned the consequences of a no-deal Brexit could spark a recession in the UK adding that house prices could plummet.Citing Cabinet sources,&nbspMr&nbspCarney said unemployment figures would reach double-figure percentages, while house prices would plummet by up to 35 percent.A report by the  last week said several sources claimed the Bank of England Governor compared a no-deal Brexit scenario to the financial crisis in 2008.One cabinet minister told the newspaper: &ldquoThe Government wouldn&rsquot just stand by. It didn&rsquot in 2008.Brexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg ripped into Mark Carney's Brexit warnings (Image: &bullLBC)&ldquoHe wasn&rsquot saying it was all going to happen but I think there is a recognition that you do have to contemplate the worst-case scenario.It was announced last week that the Bank of England boss will continue his role until January 2020 in order to &ldquosupport a smooth and successful Brexit.On Thursday the Bank of England kept interest rates on hold.The&nbspstabilisation&nbspof interest rates came just a month after it raised borrowing costs for just the second time in more than a decade.Express has contacted the Bank of England for comment.

title: scotland news dog control order asbos
story: The number dog &ldquoAsbos issued in Scotland has soared, according to official figures (Image: )In 2011, councils were given powers to issue dog control notices (DCNs) ordering irresponsible owners to muzzle their pets, keep them on a lead or attend training courses.All dogs issued with a DCN are also implanted with a microchip.If the dog control orders are breached, owners face a fine of up to &pound1,000.In extreme cases, the dog could be put down.                Sickening CCTV captures moment injured dog is dumped on a doorstep                Dog-lover tells MSPs: End pet bans in rented homesSince DCNs came into force, through the Control of Dogs (Scotland) Act 2010, the number handed out each year has jumped from 92 to 339.The figures, which emerged in a Scottish Government response to a parliamentary question from the Conservatives, 147 were issued in 2012-13.This rose to 244 the following year and 277 in 2014-15. It stayed at 290 for two years before climbing again to 339 in 2017-18.Fife Council handed out the most at 311, followed by West Lothian with 126.In 2011, councils were given powers to issue DCNs ordering irresponsible owners to muzzle their pets (Image: )Inverclyde Council issued just three over the period, while East Renfrewshire handed out two.Glasgow reported three notices but figures were not available for 2016-17 and 2017-18Scottish Tory MSP Maurice Golden described the figures as &ldquoconcerning as they suggested dog owners were increasingly failing to look after their pets properly.He said: &ldquoIt indicates more incidents of &lsquoout of control&rsquo dogs have taken place and people have been put at risk.&ldquoLocal authorities must use the powers they have to intervene meaningfully to ensure that no one is at risk from a dangerous dog.In July Holyrood&rsquos Public Audit and Post-Legislative Scrutiny Committee announced a probe into the legislation.Recent figures show the number of people who received treatment for dog bites rose from 1,939 in 2015 to 2,027 in 2016.

title: john swinney p1 tests snp vote scotland nicola sturgeon
story: John Swinney was accused of arrogance (Image: NC)The Education Secretary was accused of arrogance after he repeatedly refused to say if his government will respect a Holyrood ballot on their future.Opposition parties have united behind a Labour motion calling for the tests to be scrapped, and the Tories will use their business time in the chamber on Wednesday to hold a vote.Teachers have complained the standardised assessments have left P1 pupils in tears and are a &ldquouseless way to test a child&rsquos ability.A separate boycott campaign among parents is also under way.                Nicola Sturgeon opens up about childhood bullying                 Sturgeon accused of selling &lsquoSNAKE OIL&rsquo and hoodwinking voters Nicola Sturgeon has refused to confirm that she would respect parliament&rsquos will and scrap the tests for four and five-year-olds.Although not legally binding, any defeat will be embarrassing for the First Minister, who has claimed education is her &ldquotop priority.Mr Swinney was pressed six times on BBC&rsquos Sunday Politics Scotland programme on the issue but would not say what would happen, if as expected parliament votes to scrap them.He said: &ldquoWe&rsquoll see what parliament comes up with on Wednesday.Nicola Sturgeon has refused to confirm that she would respect parliament&rsquos will (Image: )&ldquoParliamentary motions are not binding on the government, the only thing that&rsquos binding on the government is legislation.&ldquoSo, we&rsquoll reflect on whatever parliament produces on Wednesday in the debate but we will make the very strong, evidenced argument for primary one standardised assessments because it&rsquos part of the integral process of learning for young people within Scotland and it&rsquos important that we identify at the earliest possible opportunity the needs of young people and support them to overcome those challenges.But Scottish Lib Dem leader Willie Rennie said: &ldquoThis was an astoundingly arrogant intervention from the Education Secretary.&ldquoI&rsquove worked all my life for a democratic Scottish Parliament and I find it astonishing that a Government minister could contemplate plowing onward if parliament expressly instructed him to stop.                SNP under pressure to deliver 'TOURIST TAX' in the Highlands                Scottish parents 'IN THE DARK' due to 'SHAMEFUL' SNP education policyIain Gray, for Scottish Labour, described Mr Swinney&rsquos remarks as a &ldquothinly veiled threat to ignore the will of the Scottish Parliament.He added: &ldquoIt&rsquos time for Mr Swinney to put the children of Scotland ahead of his ego and bin these tests.Tory education spokesman Liz Smith said it was clear &ldquothere are major issues about both the introduction and delivery of Primary 1 tests.She said: &ldquoGiven the strength of the evidence, Mr Swinney would be wise to listen to the points raised and consider the outcome very carefully.It came after Mr Swinney launched a &ldquodesperate last-ditch attempt to avoid defeat by arguing it would be &ldquodeeply irresponsible to scrap the tests.He claimed critics have often been &ldquoill-informed and accused rivals of hypocrisy with Labour, Tory and the Lib Dem councils using carrying out their own P1 tests before the national assessments came in.Mr Swinney has also written to rivals offering a &ldquodrop-in demonstration session of the assessments, performed by civil servants on Tuesday.

title: glasgow university scotland slave trade
story: Glasgow University Principal Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli  (Image: NC)The university carried out a year-long study into thousands of donations made in the 18th and 19th centuries and discovered some were linked to slave trade profits.Creating a centre for the study of slavery and memorial or tribute in university grounds in the name of the enslaved has now been agreed by the university as part of a reparative justice programme.The research identified 16 bursaries, endowments and mortifications donated between 1809 and 1937 with direct links to profits from slavery.Donations to the 1866-1880 campaign to build current campus at Gilmorehill found 23 people who gave money had some financial links to the New World slave trade.                Judy Murray blasts lack of tennis courts in Glasgow                Glasgow has no Michelin restaurants because Scots won&rsquot payIn total, the money received is estimated as having a present day value of between &pound17 million and &pound199 million.Glasgow University Principal Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli said: &ldquoThis report has been an important undertaking and commitment to find out if the university benefited from slavery in the past.&ldquoAlthough the university never owned enslaved people or traded in the goods they produced, it is now clear we received significant financial support from people whose wealth came from slavery.&ldquoThe university deeply regrets this association with historical slavery which clashes with our proud history of support for the abolition of both the slave trade and slavery itself.He highlighted the university&rsquos historic anti-slavery activity which included petitioning Parliament to abolish slavery, awarding an honorary degree to the emancipationist, William Wilberforce, and educating former slave James McCune Smith, who became the first ever African American to receive a medical degree.

title: Brexit news Theresa May Chequers deal brexit eu latest BBC Panorama
story: Theresa May claimed the &ldquoalternative to Chequers was a Brexit no deal, during BBC Panorama, &lsquoInside No 10: Deal or No Deal?&rsquo.Mrs May has been under pressure from MPs within her own party to &ldquochuck Chequers with some MP's claiming the agreement does not deliver what the British people voted for.Leading Brexit supporter Jacob Rees-Mogg told the BBC the Government would be &ldquofoolish to place a Chequers-based agreement with the EU in front of MPs in Parliament as the they would find the deal had &ldquovery little support.He said: &ldquoThis is the sort of Dirty Harry Option, it&rsquos 'come on punk, make my day'. How many shots have been fired? If you make the wrong choice, consequences could be unpleasant.                Boris warns Irish backstop plan leaves UK 'effectively in the EU'                Nigel Farage EXPLODES after radio caller brands him 'dangerous'BBC presenter Nick Robinson asked the Prime Minister about&nbspMr&nbspRees-Moggs remarks, before&nbspTheresa&nbspMay explained the alternative to Chequers was a Brexit no deal.She said: &ldquoLook, every member of Parliament, when it comes to that vote, I am sure they will&nbsprecognise&nbspthe significance of that vote.&ldquoDo we really think that if the European Union had been through this negotiation and get to point that we have&nbspagreed&nbspa deal, that Parliament was to say &lsquono, go back and get a better one&rsquo, do we really think the European Union is going to give a better deal at that point?The BBC host pressed the Prime Minister asking whether she was saying it is &ldquomy deal or no deal?.&nbspMrs&nbspMay said: &ldquoI think that the alternative to that will be having no deal.&ldquoA, I don&rsquot think the negotiations would have that deal. And B, we are leaving on the 29 March 2019.Labour&rsquos shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer claimed if&nbspMrs&nbspMay&rsquos Brexit agreement was defeated, then the question should go back to the electorate.He said: &ldquoIf the deal doesn&rsquot carry, if she doesn&rsquot actually have the confidence of Parliament, or she can&rsquot even reach an agreement, we will be staring at no deal.&ldquoThat can&rsquot be allowed to happen. In those&nbspcircumstances,&nbspall options should on the table. And one of those has to bed the ability to put the question back to the electorate.Brexit news: Theresa May claimed if Chequers was voted down the other option is no-deal (Image: BBC)On Sunday, Environment Secretary Michael Gove&nbspsuggestion&nbspthe Prime Minister&rsquos controversial Chequers agreement was not &ldquopermanent.He said: &ldquoNo, I think it&rsquos the right answer. A future Prime Minister could always choose to alter the relationship between Britain and the European Union but the Chequers approach is the right one for now.During the BBC Panorama, which aired on Monday evening, the Prime Minister also claimed that the &ldquobloody difficult woman is still there.She went on: There's a difference between those who think you can only be bloody difficult in public, and those who think actually you bide your time, and you're bloody difficult when the time is right - and when it really matters.She added: We are in a negotiation, we are going to be sitting down. We are going to be looking at this plan. I have been very clear, those issues of which are absolutely non-negotiable.&ldquoAn end to free movement, non-negotiable. An end to the jurisdiction of the European Union, non-negotiable. And end to sending vast sums of money to the European Union every year, non-negotiable.Mrs&nbspMay&rsquos Chequers plan has received criticism from former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, who resigned over the plan in July.Downing Street has reiterated there is no alternative plan to the Chequers deal.

title: finance news uk savings rate bank of england base rate interest record low
story: The Bank of England recently hiked interest rates to 0.75 per cent but savers are still suffering (Image: )It means millions of savers, who have suffered more than a decade of paltry returns while interest rates have been at record lows, are still waiting for a fair deal.The scandal has sparked another round of rip-off claims aimed at banks and building societies who have been quick to increase mortgage payments.Some 69 per cent of savings accounts pay a rate above 0.75 per cent, analysis by Moneyfacts has found.It puts the proportion of accounts paying above the base rate at its lowest level since January 2013 when it was 68 per cent.                UK financial services ARE READY for NO deal Brexit declares CEODespite two rate rises from the Bank of England, savers are not seeing much improvement in rates (Image: )The base rate was increased from 0.5 per cent in August, but consumer groups have accused providers of double standards when passing on the rate change to savers and borrowers.Charlotte Nelson, finance expert at Moneyfacts, said: &ldquoIt is a sorry state of affairs that, despite two rate rises from the Bank of England, savers are still not seeing any real improvement in rates.&ldquoIn fact, the average easy access account has only risen by 0.04 per cent since August 2016 and more shockingly, the average easy-access Isa has fallen over the last two years by 0.08 per cent.The situation is unlikely to improve until all the funding from Government schemes &ndash such as the Term Funding Scheme &ndash disappears and bigger banks stop trading off their names and offer savers a decent return, added Ms Nelson.However, savers continue to flock to easy-access accounts, ploughing &pound18billion into them since the start of the year, figures from the Bank of England show.Millions of savers are still waiting for a fair deal  (Image: )Ms Nelson said: &ldquoWith a substantial chunk of the easy-access market paying less than the base rate, it is likely a large proportion of this cash is sitting in poor-paying accounts.&ldquoNow is not the time for savers to rest on their laurels. In order to achieve a decent return, they must work hard and actively shop around to maximise their interest.Samantha Seaton, chief executive of Moneyhub, said: &ldquoMany banks are too slow to pass on the benefit of a rate rise, so it&rsquos vital savers actively look for other options to help their money grow.Consumer champion Which? found earlier this month that around two-thirds of instant access variable savings accounts had failed to see any benefit so far from the rate rise on August 2.Meanwhile, almost half (48 per cent) of providers had raised their standard variable mortgage rates by the full 0.25 per cent.                New York overtakes London as world&rsquos most attractive financial cen...It is now easier than ever to shop around for the best deal and ISAs are an option too  (Image:  STOCK)Harry Rose, Which? money editor, said: &ldquoWhen news of the Bank&rsquos 0.25 per cent base rate rise was announced last month, many savers will have assumed that things were finally looking up after more than a decade of ultra-low returns. But the banks had other ideas.&ldquoIn the month since, long-suffering savers have been left wondering if they&rsquoll see any boost at all as numerous banks and building societies refused to pass on the increase.&ldquoWhile half of mortgage providers swiftly hiked their rates by the full amount, the vast majority of savings rates stayed the same.&ldquoWhile homeowners quickly faced higher bills, savers missed out. And this double standard is now par for the course. It was the same last year after the previous rate rise.&ldquoIn the worst cases, providers have readily hoisted mortgage rates by the full 0.25 per cent, but not passed on a single benefit to their savings customers.&ldquoBanks and building societies have no good excuse for this behaviour.&ldquoFor a banking sector still struggling to regain trust after the financial crisis, we must see fairness for consumers.Kate Smith, of investment specialists Aegon, said: &ldquoIt&rsquos disappointing but not unexpected to see the banks&rsquo reluctance to pass on the interest rate to savers, while at the same time increasing mortgage rates.&ldquoThese &lsquodouble standards&rsquo aren&rsquot new but with the proportion of savings accounts on the market paying above the Bank of England base rate sinking to a five-year low, consumers are set to feel the effects on their savings in the long-run.&ldquoConsumers should consider the full range of investment options available to them and weigh up whether or not they should move at least some funds out of cash savings accounts and into Isa stocks and shares.A spokeswoman for the lenders&rsquo trade body UK Finance said: &ldquoLast month&rsquos rate rise will impact businesses and consumers in different ways depending on the nature of the lending and savings products they hold.&ldquoBanks have made it easier for customers to shop around to get the best deal for them, including clearer communications about the rates they receive, faster cash Isa transfers and stronger customer prompts before a rate is reduced.&ldquoAny customers looking for a better rate should always shop around to look for the best deals on offer.

title: Brexit news Theresa May EU citizens rights UK immigration plans
story: Theresa May strongly hinted EU migrants will not get a preferential treatment (Image: Getty)The Prime Minister stated the British people are seeking a fairer immigration system where all migrants are treated the same, without preferential treatment.The new post-Brexit system is likely to be unveiled by the Prime Minister in her Conservative Party conference speech in Birmingham, and she has summoned members to a special meeting on September 24, only a week before.However, during a BBC Panorama interview, Mrs May gave the strongest hint yet on what the blueprint will likely include regarding automatic rights for EU citizens.Mrs May said: &ldquoWhat I&rsquom very clear about is the message from the British people was very simple.                French MP slams EU handling of Europe migration crisis&ldquoIt was they didn&rsquot want a situation where they could see people coming from the European Union having those automatic rights in terms of coming here to the United Kingdom, and a set of rules for people outside the European Union.What we will be doing is putting forward a set of rules for people from the European Union and people from outside the European Union.Mrs May's remarks could mean that when Britain leaves the bloc, European migrants could be subject to non-EU citizen restrictions, including visa applications.Caps could also be put in place on the number of skilled and unskilled workers entering the UK from the EU.It is likely the PM will unveil the new immigration plans during her Tory conference speech  (Image: Getty)However, Whitehall sources have predicted a tense showdown over migration due to concerns over the scheme from colleagues including Chancellor Philip Hammond and Business Secretary Greg Clark.Mr Hammond was reported to want to promote a scheme which would not cut EU migration, so that the economy would continue to benefit from a constant supply of labour.Nevertheless, Brexiteers are likely to welcome tougher rules on EU migration and will reject any plans that promote freedom of movement.Passionate Brexiteer MP Liam Fox recently suggested the UK could use the end of freedom of movement in the aftermath of Brexit as a tool to lure international partners into investing more in the UK.                The DIRTIER the Brexit the more damage to BritainPhillip Hammond reportedly wants a scheme which would  not curb EU migration (Image: Getty)Speaking to Sophie Ridge on Sky News, the Tory Brexiteer said: It's about not having a system that's skewed towards EU citizens.We need to see that that free movement is brought to an end.From the points I have been making, it&rsquos very clear that it has its advantages, not just in terms of stopping public services being used by those who haven&rsquot contributed, but it can be an extra tool in the box when it comes to future trade negotiations with other countries.Net migration fell below 250,000 for the first time in three tears earlier this year - but it remains over the promised 100,000 target first set by David Cameron in 2010.Mrs May has previously hinted she will battle to get the level of immigration below 100,000 by 2022 - the end of the next five-year Parliament despite pressure from her own Cabinet to ditch the controversial target.

title: brexit news vince cable theresa may second eu referendum liberal democrat conference
story: Vince Cable will call on Theresa May to &ldquoshock us all and demand a second referendum  (Image: )In what is likely to be Sir Vince Cable's last conference speech as leader of the Liberal Democrats, the 75-year-old is expected to call on Theresa May to &ldquoshock us all and call for a second EU referendum.Sir Vince will outline how voters are &ldquostarting to feel sorry for Mrs May who is dutifully delivering a policy she does not really believe in because of her enemies in the Conservative Party.The leader of the Lib Dems is expected to say: I would go so far as to say that some of us are starting to feel sorry for the Prime Minister.It seems that even the European leaders are moved to pity. It is obvious why.She is dutifully delivering a policy she doesn't really believe in failing in negotiations losing public support and all to appease a dwindling group of angry people in her party who will denounce her as a traitor, whatever she comes up with.                Brexit IMMIGRATION plans: May hints EU migrants WON&rsquoT get automatic...But, when we feel sorry for the country's Prime Minister, something is seriously wrong.Our sympathy can only extend so far, while she puts the interests of the country second to the whims of the extremists in her party.He will suggest that the Prime Minister &ldquoknows Brexit is a bad idea, and will call on her to display &ldquotrue leadership by calling for a second referendum.He will say: &ldquoShe could admit that the Brexit project has gone badly wrong by conceding that the deal - any deal, or no deal - that she will bring back from Brussels is not going to be better for Britain than remaining in the European Union.Sir Vince is expected to patronise the Prime Minister (Image: )Vince Cable is part of the People&rsquos Vote campaign (Image: )Voters are &ldquostarting to feel sorry for Theresa May according to Vince Cable  (Image: )Instead of kow-towing to her enemies in the Conservative Party, she could lead her party and the country by opening her mind to a 'people's vote' on the final deal.However, Mrs May has ruled out a second referendum under any circumstances.The Prime Minister told the BBC earlier today MPs would have a choice between her proposed deal or a &lsquono deal&rsquo outcome, ahead of the UK's highly anticipated departure.However, Sir Vince has argued there are apparently &ldquobetter alternatives and vowed to do everything he can to stop Brexit in the Commons.                Chequers Brexit deal explained: What is the Chequers Brexit deal?                BREXIT BREAKTHROUGH: Brussels on the brink of a climb down The MP for Twickenham is part of the People&rsquos Vote campaign for another referendum and says support is growing despite putting its chances of success at 30 percent.In his speech in Brighton, Sir Vince - who has said he will step down when Brexit has been resolved or stopped - will also say: &ldquoFor the 'true believers' - the fundamentalists - the costs of Brexit have always been irrelevant.Years of economic pain justified by the erotic spasm of leaving the European Union.Economic pain felt - of course, not by them - by those least able to afford it.Theresa May has ruled out another referendum under any circumstances (Image: )And the latest piece of nastiness from Jacob Rees-Mogg - calling into question the right of Europeans to stay in Britain, and of Britons to stay in Europe - creating unnecessary worry and insecurity for millions.The public don't mind what these people dream about behind closed doors - so long as their dreams don't become nightmares for the rest of us.It really beggars belief that the army and the police are now being asked to prepare for riots in the chaotic aftermath of a botched Brexit.And billions, billions, of taxpayers' money spent preparing for disaster.

title: uk weather forecast storm ali storm helene met office forecast latest
story: There is a chance that this weather system could turn into Storm Ali (Image: WXCHARTS)And if it achieves sufficient power, the weather system will be known as Storm Ali, in accordance with the naming convention adopted by the Met Office and Met &Eacuteireann, the Irish meteorological service.With hurricane season in the Atlantic Ocean well underway, recent weeks have seen several storms brewing, most notably Hurricane Florence, while Helene has been on a collision course with the UK for several days.Helene is due to arrive tonight, with winds of up to 70mph likely to batter central and western England before it passes over Scotland and out into the North Sea.Luke Miall, Meteorologist at Met Office told Express: &ldquoAfter Storm Helene, we won&rsquot have any named storms, but wet and windy weather.                Hurricane Helene arrives TONIGHT: 70mph winds to BATTER central reg...                Storm Helene MAP LIVE: Met Office issues weather warnings for MILLIONS&ldquoFor Wednesday, in particular, we are expecting low pressure to move North West of the UK, it will be quite wet and quite windy.&ldquoWe have a yellow warning in place for the wind, it covers all of Scotland, all of Northern Ireland, Northern England and North West of Wales, so quite a large area.&ldquoWe are likely to see wind gusts of potentially 50-60mph, in western Scotland perhaps even 75pmh.&ldquoIt will be combined with heavy rains, so it will be a tricky start to the day, causing travel disruption, trees possibly falling and general disruption.The WXCHARTS graphic shows a weather system following in the wake of Storm Helene (Image: WXCHARTS)Mr Miall said Scotland was likely to see more than an inch-and-half of rain fall within 24 hours, starting on Tuesday evening.He said: &ldquoThere are no warnings in place for southern England.&ldquoWe are expecting a spell of wet and wind, for Thursday, uncertain as to where, possibly in northern England and Northern Ireland, but not as bad as what will be brought by storm Helen and Wednesday&rsquos winds.Mr Miall said storms were named depending on the impact they were likely to have, admitting that there was still time for Helene&rsquos successor to make a name for itself.                UK weather forecast Met Office map: What time will Storm Helene hit?Storm Helene is due to lash the UK tonight (Image: WXCHARTS)He said: &ldquoAt the moment, the weather warning is assessed as low impact.&ldquoBut if the warning will be increased to medium, this storm could be named.&ldquoAt this stage is not been named.&ldquoThere are risks of minor flooding to roads &ndash large puddles, but the river system should be able to cope since we have seen a fairly dry period so far.The Met Office is predicting web and windy weather tomorrow, followed by further spells of wet and very windy weather in northern and west parts of the country from Wednesday onwards.However, there are likely to be some spells of sunshine on Friday, coupled with more rain.Because it started far out into the Atlantic, Helene was actually named by the World Meteorological Organisation, rather than the Met Office, which last week unveiled the list of names it will use for storms in the event that they become sufficiently powerful.Ali is the first name on the list, which currently stretches to 21 names ending in Wyn. The letters Q and U have been left out.

title: what brexit deal theresa may chequers agreement plan
story: The Prime Minister, however, faces substantial opposition from within the Conservative Party to the plan. Heres what you need to know.After a marathon session of talks at Chequers on July 6, Theresa May managed to secure a Brexit plan which will be assessed by the EU.Her Brexit plan will see the UK remains closely tied to the Brussels.It also includes the creation of a new UK-EU free trade area for goods, with a common rulebook.This rulebook could limit the UKs ability to strike trade deals with countries such as the US, for whom securing market access for American farmers would be a big prize.Mrs May has agreed to an amendment that would stop Britain being tied to Europes customs union after we quit the EU.In dramatic scenes in the House of Commons on July 17 2018, Mrs May managed to see off a damaging attempt, winning by just six votes.Mrs May was then defeated on a separate amendment to her flagship Trade Bill, which will require her to seek continued UK participation in the EUs system for regulation of medicines after Brexit.Now her Cabinet is required to ensure that the UK can continue to participate in the regulatory network operated by the European Medicines Agency.Mrs May hopes to get an agreement hammered out at a series of summits with EU leaders this autumn, and bring it back to Parliament for approval.A deal on the UKs withdrawal agreement was expected to be agreed in time for the summit in October, along with a statement from both sides on the future relationship.However, a number of senior figures have said this deadline may slide into November.Once a dead has been agreed, MPs will be asked to approve it.The former Foreign Secretary claimed Mrs Mays disastrous plans for the Irish border would leave Britain at a loss.Boris Johnson said the European Unions fallback position for the Irish border would mean Northern Ireland was annexed by Brussels.Opposition to the plan in the Conservative Party centres around the European Research Group of hard - Brexit supporting MPs led by Jacob Rees - Mogg.His voice had been among the loudest voicing their objection to the plan and he urged MPs “chuck Chequers”.Up to 80 Tory MPs are prepared to vote against Theresa Mays Chequers plan, Steve Baker, a former Brexit minister and ERG backer has warned.A group of about 50 Tory MPs have met to discuss how and when they could force her out of her job, the BBC reported.Also voicing his opposition to the Chequers deal has been former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.He said Theresas Mays had wrapped a suicide vest around the British constitution and handed the detonator to Brussels.Along with former Brexit secretary David Davis and Mr Johnson resigned in protest following the Chequers meeting.Several other MPs also quit their ministerial posts over the issue, including Steve Baker, Maria Caulfield, Ben Bradley and Robert Courts.The party will vote down any Brexit deal brought back from Brussels by Theresa May, according to shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry.The Corbyn ally said the party will oppose it to try to force an election by Christmas.Speaking to the FT she said a deal which meets her party’s tests was “not going to happen”, and therefore the Prime Minister would be forced to quit.Without the support of the opposition party, it would need just a handful of Tory rebels to vote against her to see it defeated.Theresa Mays initial plans brought her on side with those Conservatives who favour a soft Brexit.The Prime Minister has also been seeking grassroots Tory support for the plan.Among those voicing support for the Prime Minister has been Environment Secretary Michael Gove, who was a prominent member of the Leave campaign.He said he was confident that the Prime Minister will go into the Conservative Party conference and beyond, securing a good Brexit deal for Britain and continuing to ensure the country enjoys good economic growth and we take advantage of Brexit.     A plan may have been cooked up but it still needs to get past the EU — and the continent’s leaders are showing no sign of compromise.Angela Merkel is already rubbishing our proposal.The Napoleonic Emmanuel Macron thinks he’s a political messiah, and he’d rather see us punished than give up on his federalist promised land.And Michel Barnier’s dangled “concessions” amount to a demand for total UK capitulation.With that level of zeal and stubbornness, it’s no wonder we voted in our millions to leave.We must now go to Brussels with an offer that guarantees control of our borders and sign our own trade deals.But we mustn’t for a second think that they’ll just say yes to it, nor can the PM let them fatally weaken it.It is galling that ministers have spent more time fighting between themselves than preparing for a “no deal” exit.But it isn’t too late.New technology can ensure that Whitehall and our borders are ready for a clean break, which considering the strength of our economy and our companies is nothing to be scared of.The PM has dumped many of her earlier Brexit slogans. But she should remember one in particular now.No deal really is better than a bad deal, and we must still prepare for it.

title: josie russell is a walking testament to the power of human spirit her mum would be very proud
story: In 1996, when she was just nine years old, she survived a hammer attack that killed her mum Lin and little sister Megan.The three of them were walking down a quiet country lane near the Kent village of Chillenden when they were tied up, blindfolded and ­repeatedly beaten.Josie’s mum and sister were found dead at the scene. The ­family’s beloved pet dog was also killed by deranged Michael Stone.Josie herself was left with such severe head injuries that medics at she scene thought she was dead before finding a faint pulse.This little girl was a fighter.It must have been horrendous for both of them.Josie couldn’t speak for a year after the attack, had to have an operation to put a titanium plate in her head and her recovery was slow. It was all about small ­victories, and it was down to the tenacity of a little girl who just wanted to live a normal le.Now she is flourishing.Josie has become a successful artist, is engaged to her soul mate Iwan Jones and recently bought the family home in Wales where she spent her early childhood before they all moved to Kent where the attack happened.The house is full of happy memories and Josie dwells on events like her mum bringing home Rosie the pony when she was just five years old and teaching her to ride.Rosie is now a grand old lady of 27 and one of the most ­important things in Josie’s le.The feisty little pony is a link to her mum and little sister and played a massive part in her recovery. Learning how to ride again gave her confidence and a sense of freedom.Josie graduated with a degree in graphic design in 2009 and built up her own art business, first by selling handmade cards at fairs and now producing beautul ­textile landscapes.I’ve met Josie several times over the years, most memorably shortly after the accident when she was still coming to terms with the double tragedy of the death of both her mum and sister.She was shy and wary but gradually I gained her confidence and we spent a lovely afternoon together with her dad Shaun and Rosie the pony.I caught up with her again this week, and I’m always struck by her positivity and her refusal to be thought of as a victim.She very much lives in the moment and always tries to seize the day and be positive.Josie is a walking testament to the power of the human spirit and her mum would be very proud of her beautul, talented, happy daughter.LOTS of speculation already over who will be heading Down Under for I’m A Celebrity in November.Names being bandied around include EastEnder Danny Dyer, Corrie’s Michael Le Vell and former Strictly pro Brendan Cole.GMB’s Kate Garraway is keeping mum about rumours but she would be a hoot, although the person I’d really like to see there is my pal and TV colleague Dr Hilary Jones, who we’ve mocked up in the jungle, pictured.A team player and an action man, he also has a filthy sense of humour, doesn’t suffer fools gladly and would dispense medicine and advice when the insects start to bite and tummies get upset after being fed a diet of ostrich bum.And at the risk of objectying the good doctor, I would pay good money to see him in his skimpies having a shower at the famous waterfall.The ambitious project was first discussed in 2004, when I was rector of Dundee University. It’s wonderful to see it spring to le.Inevitably, costs spiralled. But hopefully the increase in tourism, business and the jobs created will more than offset the £80million price tag.As a proud adopted Dundonian, I want the V&ampA to be a museum for everyone. I hope schoolchildren will enjoy the exhibits, friends will meet there for coffee and everyone in Dundee will think of it as their own.It’s here and I can’t wait to celebrate.IT’S a bit icky – and frankly unbelievable – that Corrie has Jim McDonald pretending his current girlfriend is his dead daughter in order to wreak revenge on his clan.More Game Of Thrones than a game of dominoes down the Rovers... and I can’t take it seriously., so I am. I’ve missed him bellowing “ELIZABETH!” and talking about being in the big house, so I have.I just wish they hadn’t oversensationalised his  because the character is big enough not to need such an OTT comeback.It did get me thinking as to who else I would like to see back in Soapland.And one fab character sprang to mind. I’m sure you recall Emmerdale’s Paul Lambert, who made a huge impact during his five years in the Dales.Paul was played by the ridiculously handsome Mathew Bose, who must have a painting in the attic because he hasn’t aged a day since leaving school.Surely his  is long overdue. His family are still in Emmerdale, including dad Rodney Blackstock, auntie Diane Sugden and his half-sisters. There are lots of layers to Paul, too.His alter-ego is drag queen Thelma Louise, while he and his boyfriend Jonny were the first characters in a primetime drama to have a civil partnership, back in 2008.Surely such an interesting character should be welcomed back to Emmerdale with open arms.We will know more tomorrow night, but I’m spending far more time than is good for me speculating about how it’s all going to be resolved.IT’S been a long time since I considered Jacob Rees-Mogg an amusing anachronism, a bit like a pocket watch.Behind this softly spoken throwback to the Victorian age is a flinty hard-liner who would deny a raped woman the right to an abortion.He’s hell-bent on a rock-hard Brexit, and he doth protest too much about not wanting to be Prime Minister for it to ring true. So it’s fair to say I’m not a fan.But I was appalled by the rude, ignorant mob of “class warriors” who heckled his kids and their elderly nanny outside the family home this week.It was cruel, savage and out of order. Rees-Mogg has chosen to be a politician and is used to being barracked.His children, however, are NOT public figures. They are little kids, who looked scared by the thuggish behaviour of the idiots, who did their cause no good at all.They were there to protest about the minimum wage, and one of them shouted at the children that their nanny, Veronica Crook, wasn’t paid very much to “wipe their bottoms”.Veronica, who has been with the family for half a century, was not best pleased by this, and in a brisk, no-nonsense way defended her boss and ushered her charges indoors. You got the feeling she would dearly have loved to give the protesters a very hard stare and sit them on the naughty step.Politicians from all sides expressed their disgust but those responsible don’t think they have done anything wrong.The minimum wage is well worth fighting for, but not like this.The demonstrators managed to humanise Rees-Mogg, and gained him bucketloads of sympathy. A spectacular own goal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: may must walk tall in the mountains sell brexit
story: On Wednesday night in Salzburg, Austria, she will have a chance to try to persuade other EU leaders to bite on her plan for Britain’s future relationship with the bloc.The next morning EU leaders will meet without her, to decide on their response. May needs them to say or, preferably, do something that shows her plan is making headway and is a realistic way forward.“The Government has got to show that it is making some progress,” admits one leading Cabinet minister.No one in Downing Street is expecting a dramatic breakthrough at this summit, though.Theresa May told the Cabinet this week that Salzburg would be a “staging post” on the way to a deal.The British hope is that on Thursday, the EU will announce a special November meeting to discuss Brexit. That, combined with the October EU Council, should provide time for a deal to be done.But, in a sign of how the timetable could slip further, one Downing Street figure close to the negotiations has told influential Europeans that  a deal was done in December, the Government could still get it through parliament in time for Brexit day.Others in No10  are insistent that the withdrawal agreement needs to be done by November. What May needs to judge though is whether the EU is serious about engaging with her Chequers plan or not.Influential Cabinet ministers are worried that the EU will never formally kill off Chequers but will not ever really take it seriously. Then at the last, May will be left with only two options when it comes to  getting a withdrawal agreement.She would either have to leave Northern Ireland in the customs territory of the EU — a ision of the UK that May has repeatedly said is unacceptable.Or, sign the whole of the UK up to a customs union with the EU, which she has, again, said she does not want to do as it would deny Britain an independent trade policy.If she does not want to take either of these bad deals, she would be left with No Deal.The Government still hopes that the member states, who are accountable to their electorates for the consequences of no deal, will tell the Commission to be more flexible as the clock ticks down.  But Chequers, which was sold to the Cabinet on the basis it was “negotiable”, has not yet made the progress many in Government hoped it would.If this does not change soon, it will be time for Mrs May to change tack. At the same time, the Government must step up its preparations for le outside the EU.“Project After” is looking into how Britain can benefit from the freedoms it will have once it has left. But ministers tell me that it “needs more work”.This should be a priority for the Government. For Brexit does not guarantee this  country’s success or failure.  It is what we do after Brexit with our new-found  flexibility that will ­determine that.The Government must be ready to seize this moment.PHILIP HAMMOND has twice had to be slapped down by the Chief Whip in Cabinet this week.On Tuesday, he talked about how there would be a lot of “squealing” about universal credit. Julian Smith, the chief whip, then picked him up on his language.He said that talking about “squealing” doesn’t help. .Those sympathetic to Hammond say that he was talking specically about Labour when he used the word “squealing”. But it is another reminder of his political tin ear.Then on Thursday, Hammond raised the prospect of delaying Brexit day. After the ­legislative timetable for getting ready for “no deal” – which is tight –  had been outlined, Hammond pointed out that the Government has the power to put the Brexit date back.But doing this would be politically explosive.No one else present supported Hammond’s point and the chief whip shot it down, saying they would get all the legislation through in time.Theresa May then explicitly ruled out delaying Brexit day. Allies of Hammond say that he was only talking about an administrative pause of a few weeks.They argue that he only made the point after Andrea Leadsom, the leader of the House of Commons, raised concerns about there not being enough parliamentary time to get everything in place.But Any delay in exit day would cause a massive political crisis. No10 ­sources are adamant that there is “zero chance” of Brexit day not being March  29, 2019.But there is a major problem for the ­Government when the Chancellor, one of the three most senior figures in it, has such a political tin ear that he raises the prospect.This date would make things all too easy for the Government’s critics. It would be “The Zombie ­Budget”, “Hammond’s ­horror show”, “The bloodsucking Budget”.So, a Halloween Budget is out. No final date has yet been agreed for it. But the aim is for the Budget to take place before the special November EU Brexit summit.The Government does not want to risk the Budget ­getting caught up in the row over Theresa May’s ­negotiating position.So keen is the Government to keep these two events separate, there is even talk of breaking with tradition and possibly ­holding the Budget on a Monday .WHILE Boris Johnson has been keeping up a regular verbal barrage against Theresa May’s Chequers plan, she has not given it the hard sell.There has been no national tour, no fireside chat with the country or impassioned speech.But next week, Theresa May will try and make the case for her plan in an extended interview with Panorama. The BBC show was even allowed to film the start of Thursday’s “no-deal” Cabinet.Number 10’s view is that most voters don’t know what the Chequers plan means. They think that a lot of those who are hostile to it, particularly on the Tory side, are more aware of the row over it –  and particularly the resignations of Boris and David Davis – than the details of the plan.If the Prime Minister  though is going to persuade sceptical voters of the merit of her approach, she needs to admit that something has changed and explain why.It won’t work  she simply says she’s stuck rigidly to her red lines.Instead, she needs to ask voters to put themselves in her shoes, to under­stand why she has made the trade-offs that she has.Mrs May must treat the electorate like grown-ups.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chancellor philip hammond is determined to prove hes a liability to government
story: So many of its woes are down to him.It is Mr Hammond and his aides who have led a Remain resistance from Downing Street, scuttling  no-deal preparations and ceaselessly doom-mongering.It is Mr Hammond who, just as  Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab talked up the benefits of a no-deal, undermined him by publishing his own dire warnings.It is Mr Hammond who suggests delaying Brexit — a politically insane idea and a gt to the second referendum mob.And it is Mr Hammond who sabotaged Theresa May’s mission to help the “just about managings”. In his very first disastrous Budget he tried, and failed, to raise National Insurance for self­-employed strivers. Has he learned? No.Now he intends to scrap a tax cut for White Van Man and a scheme helping hard-up Brits to start a business. He is plotting to hit drivers with the first fuel duty rise in years. And not content with taxing fizzy drinks, he targets the  CUPS.One sneaky grab after another, from people already struggling. What part of “just about managing” doesn’t he grasp?Mr Hammond is a glum, grey, blinkered bean-counter with no vision, political nous or clue how hard le is for the low-paid. His instincts, not to lower taxes from a 30-year high but to raise them, have no place in a Tory Treasury.Can the upcoming Budget reprieve him? We doubt it.SOME rail services are a disgrace, a ­grotesque betrayal of paying customers.So we welcome the review into their future. If it nails the myth that renationalisation is the answer, all the better.A frustrated public seems keen to take trains back into state hands. Older people have only dim memories of British Rail’s endless strikes, late trains, filthy carriages and lousy food. Younger generations weren’t born to experience it.Some private firms do run a great service. Others give the  system a bad name.Fares are too high and absurdly complex. Franchises are regional monopolies with no need to compete — all of them vulnerable to union blackmail.It is high time Transport Secretary Chris Grayling got to grips with it.THE Lib Dems won’t fool anyone with the “rebranding” Vince Cable fancies.The “New Liberal Democrats” would not be new, liberal or democratic.Reheated Blair ideas aren’t new.A party committed to state regulation of the Press and maintaining the EU’s protectionist trade policies isn’t liberal.And champions of democracy don’t fixate on overthrowing the biggest ­ballot box ­mandate in our history.Back to the blank slate, Vince.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady column alcohol vanity good health
story: One day, butter is the enemy. The next it’s sugar. Then carbs. A few weeks later, sugar is back on the naughty step.It’s the same with alcohol. Until recently, a glass of wine a day kept heart attacks at bay. Last month, we learned that NO amount of alcohol is safe. Then this week our new goal, apparently, should be two teetotal days a week.It’s hard to keep up — and no wonder many people ignore all the reports. Who wants to be told what to do by a bunch of scientists who can’t make up their mind?But the latest news from Public Health England should give us all pause for thought, because British women now have some of the lowest le expectancies in Europe.Girls born in the UK today can expect to die three-and-a-half years earlier than girls in Spain, the country that comes out top in this report. The reasons? Rising levels of obesity and poor cancer survival rates.British women also fare badly when it comes to premature deaths — defined as before 75.Many are caused by cancer, heart disease, stroke and type 2 diabetes, which are linked to smoking, alcohol and junk food.France, home of Michelin star chefs, is also way down on the list. And so is Italy.My supporting evidence is that I live with an Italian, who would be more likely to attend a funeral in a jester’s hat than eat a bag of crisps.Clearly, we all need to take a leaf out of the same book.The prevailing wisdom is that it’s more expensive to eat healthily. But that’s not true.A recent report from the Institute of Economic Affairs shows it’s possible to have your five-a-day for less than 30p — and a nutritious,  plain, diet can be bought for less than £1 a day.Meanwhile, the cheapest adult meal in McDonald’s is about £4.50, for which you could make a fresh vegetable curry for the whole family.So it’s not about money. Why, then, do us British women fare so badly?I wonder  we are so daunted by images of women airbrushed to perfection, in adverts and on social media, we feel we can’t compete. So we give up, eating what we like and not exercising.Because keeping really fit takes serious work.The latest insight into this is from movie star Mark Wahlberg who shared his daily schedule this week.He’s in bed by 7.30pm then up at 2.30am for the first of his two daily workouts. His fitness schedule only allows for two hours’ “work” a day — and thus it becomes clear his job is, in fact, his physique.Since most of us spend at least ten hours a day working and commuting, you can see why it’s often easier not to bother.But it’s not just our health that’s in peril. It’s also that of our children, for whom we are the primary role models.Not about vanity, but good healthI have evidence in the form of my best friend, who is a marathon-running exercise junkie — as is her daughter.I, on the other hand, although not proud of this fact, do no exercise — and my daughter doesn’t enjoy it as much as her friends.Getting fit and losing weight can feel impossible.But look at Labour deputy leader Tom Watson, who this week announced that he has lost 7st and put his Type 2 diabetes in remission, which is pretty inspiring.So let’s choose to make this bad news story into a positive and use it as inspiration for change.Let’s aim for two booze-free days a week.And maybe ditch the biscuits for a bit and make some other small, sustainable changes that will leave us able to go for a brisk walk without fearing a heart attack.This is not about vanity, it’s about good health. Because the alternative is sobering.When it started off 18 years ago it was innovative and exciting TV. But now it’s degenerated into a hotbed of fame-hungry wannabes pitted against each other and behaving horribly as a result.Now it’s been axed. About time, too.I BELIEVE in people’s right to protest – of course – against political views they disagree with. But, Ian Bone, the protestor who assailed Jacob Rees-Mogg and his children on their own doorstep has crossed a line.“Your daddy is a horrible man,” Mr Bone told Mr Rees-Mogg’s bewildered-looking children, who will likely be traumatised by the incident – and will certainly not forget.MPs are already putting a lot on the line to serve their country. Many endure threats of violence or even death – and just look at what happened to Jo Cox.Yes, it’s fine to disagree with politicians and to protest. But taking it out on children and trying to make them feel bad about their father is bullying behaviour that is wholly unacceptable.Speaking to LBC afterwards, Mr Bone, who is 71, said that he saw no problem with involving children in his protest.But despite being happy to bring Mr Rees-Mogg’s offspring into the argument, he refused to speak about his own five children, and repeatedly refused to answer  he would have been happy for them to be treated in the same way.Talk about hypocritical.EVERYONE praised as progress the BBC’s “solution” to the inequality on comedy panel shows, which has been to ensure there is at least one woman on every show.But then we hear from Sandi Toksvig that their contributions are often edited out.The QI host told the Radio Times: “There are panel shows that struggle to get women on, and that’s because . . . in the edit they are often seen just laughing at the boys and not saying anything at all, even though I know for a fact in the recording they were clever.”Turns out that turning up and being funny isn’t quite enough,  you are a woman, to be given the same air time as men. How annoying.MY Woman of the Week award goes to Carol Vorderman who, at 57, is clearly in her absolute element and loving le.She looks healthy and oozes confidence, especially in these skin-tight jeans.She told ITV’s Lorraine this week she’s happy being single and is not looking for a “keeper” or another intense relationship.In fact, she said she “couldn’t think of anything worse”.How refreshing. And what a great role model she is for women in their fties and beyond.WATCHING the video of a homeless man being sprayed with paint in Middlesbrough made my blood boil.The poor man – who was found dead just days later in a cemetery – is filmed sat against a wall, covered in paint, as a man brags: “This is how we dealwith the beggars on the street.”This disregard for another human being’s dignity is obscene and the yob should be made to volunteer helping homeless people.Until he sees that dehumanising this man who had hit troubled times was the lowest of the low.DID you see Madonna’s daughter, 21-year old Lourdes hitting the runway for the Gypsy Sport Spring Summer 2019 showcase at New York Fashion Week?It’s so dispiriting, isn’t it, that the headline news about her appearance, which could have focused on so many dferent things – her incredible confidence, for one – was that . . . she hadn’t shaved her legs, top.I guess true equality will have been achieved when a woman’s hairy calves go unmentioned and are seen as neither here nor there.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tony blair nick clegg and john major meet with european leaders in secret plot to keep britain in the eu
story: The two former Prime Ministers and former Deputy Prime Minister have meet with senior politicians in Europe in bid to persuade them to stop the UK leaving the European Union.They have also been working with other prominent Remainers including Peter Mandelson.The mission was begun by Mr Clegg independently but he has taken on the role of informal co-ordinator of the group,  reported.In recent weeks Clegg he met Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister and the foreign policy team of the French president, Emmanuel Macron.He has also met senior German politicians including Bundestag president Wolfgang Schäuble and Peter Altmeier, the German economics minister.Last week Blair met senior politicians in Germany and Austria and Italy’s new interior minister, Matteo Salvini as well as the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier.Both have said they would be looking for Article 50 to be extended so a deal can be struck to remain in the EU that addresses concerns about immigration.“The aim of the visits is to persuade EU leaders that British politics has made the option of remaining inside the EU viable,” said Mr Clegg.“It is a question of pressing them to keep open the extension of the article 50 process beyond the March deadline to give UK negotiators more time including to prepare legislation on a people’s vote.“We cannot just turn the clock back to just before the 2016 referendum.“There would have to be some changes of freedom of movement - we cannot just put Humpty Dumpty back together again.”Mr Blair, who met Barnier on 18 July, said the main focus of his meetings was discuss a new common approach to immigration in the UK and EU.“You cannot deal with this Brexit issue unless you deal with the questions of immigration and the anxieties that gave rise to it,” he said.At a meeting on Wednesday night in Salzburg, Austria, Theresa May will have a chance to try to persuade other EU leaders to adopt her Chequers plan to for the future relationship with Brussels.

title: jacob rees mogg column theresa may brexit
story: The Prime Minister will head to the continent on Thursday to visit Salzburg — like Bath, a world heritage city — to discuss her Brexit or Chequers proposals with other leaders of European governments.To date the EU has been officially dismissive of the main elements of Chequers, the complex customs arrangements and continued use of European Rules to secure access to the single market.Michel Barnier, who led the negotiations for the EU, has been clear that the EU cannot accept this position.The UK must either be in the Single Market with all that goes with it — including free movement — or it may have a free trade deal instead.In a sense, he is the keeper of the Orlamme for the EU.Historically, this was a sacred banner carried into battle for the kings of France when no prisoners were to be taken.The heads of government may be more conciliatory and keener to help a fellow leader, not least as most of them face their own domestic dficulties.It is also the usual form for the EU to make a deal.It protests that it is strictly a rules-based organisation to maximise its negotiating strength but then, like an honest costermonger, makes the necessary trade.At the same time the British Government seems desperate to agree something on almost any terms.Chequers rubbed out the Prime Minister’s red lines to leave the UK “half in, half out” subject to EU regulations in crucial areas of the economy, and to the European Court of Justice.The vassal has been put in chains.This desperation means it will be important to watch carefully what comes out of Salzburg.Any deal will be hailed initially as a triumph because of the hostile comments made not only by Mr Barnier but, in his recent state of the Union speech, by Jean-Claude Juncker.Overcoming these obstacles will be portrayed as a triumph for British diplomacy.Those who hope that Brexit will continue to mean Brexit will need to stay awake.The first item to watch out for is money. There is no legal obligation to pay anything at all.This has been established by the House of Lords and no credible authority has questioned their Lordships.If we pay £40billon we must get something clear in , not just wishy-washy promises.Taxpayers would be outraged  it were otherwise.Any agreement on immigration must be examined with great care.We will doubtless be told that free movement has ended but, as Shakespeare wrote, “what’s in a name? that which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet”.There ought to be no preferential terms for new arrivals from the EU above those offered to other nations and no access to state benefits.There must be a clear dferentiation in their rights after we have left and admission must be subject to a work permit scheme focused on skilled rather than unskilled labour.The solution to the Irish question is a further area where Brexiteers must be alert. Last week the European Research Group, which I chair, produced a paper explaining how it could be answered on the EU’s terms.Obviously the UK could simply say that there will be no physical infrastructure at the border but  instead we examine what the EU does on its other borders, and see  those precedents could be followed, then no reasonable person would think a “hard” border were necessary.So far the inevitable attacks on our reports have been mere rudery. No one has found fault with facts.If Ireland were used to justy the major concessions the Government is giving then we would know the deal is a bad one based on a false premise.It would be better than any other which the EU has so far agreed but Ireland is supposed to make it impossible.The issue has been used by those who are fearful of leaving the EU to keep us bound by its rules and regulations.Inevitably these complex machinations have led to some gossip about the leadership.These stories come from all wings of the Party with pro-Europeans such as Tom Tugendhat and George Freeman suggesting it is time to move to a new generationHowever, it is worth remembering the Prime Minister’s virtues.She is determined, thorough and dutul, and in my view duty is an heroic virtue.This gives her great strength and without a clear Parliamentary majority it is not obvious that anyone else could steer the negations to a conclusion.Pitt the Younger was hailed as the pilot who weathered the storm. Changing the pilot would not affect the weather.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun most read print digital
story: Figures from PAMCo, a new governing body for the industry, show The Sun leapfrogged the Mail to become the UK’s Number 1 newsbrand, with 31.3million readers – just over half the UK population — each and every month.The Sun is the most-read newspaper during the week, with a lead of more than a quarter of a million on its closest competitor, the Mail.And in the digital world, The Sun’s 26.5million “monthly reach” sees Britain’s best news website almost two million ahead of MailOnline, only three years after relaunching from behind a paywall.The new stats have been released by the Publishers Audience Measurement Company , a brand new organisation which has replaced the old National Readership Survey.It’s the first modern calculation of readership, reflecting the way people consume the news in the 21st century.Speaking of which, make sure you download our improved app on your mobile.From the latest celebrity gossip to chats with football insiders, it’s easier to use than ever and packed full of the stuff you love. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
