story: NewsGiant rats filmed running around council house by pregnant mum-of-threeMum-of-three Rebecca Asquith revealed the awful situation in a scathing social media postShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPaul BrittonKelly-Ann Mills13:20, 17 SEP 2018Updated13:41, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/stomach-churning-footage-giant-rats-13259750,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pregnant woman claims to be at her wits end as she uploaded footage of giant rats running around her council house. Mum-of-three Rebecca Asquith said she has made numerous complaints to the council but decided to share the stomach-churning footage on social media when she got no response.  The 23-year-old - who has daughters aged three, two and 10-months - revealed the awful situation in their home in Leigh, Wigan, in a widely-shared Facebook post.   In one video, a giant rat emerges from behind her toilet and runs directly at the camera, the Manchester Evening News reports.  Rebecca said she contacted Wigan council, but it took four weeks for anyone to be sent out.   OAP risks le chasing off three armed raiders after they storm betting shop 'with hammers and shotgun'  After the footage and photographs she took as proof went viral, the council posted on social media to say it was 'treating the matter very seriously' and would 'urgently work' with the family. Rebecca, who has lived in the council house on Mersey Street for 12 months, is 33-weeks pregnant and said both rats and mice have been in the house for a few months. Her boyfriend Ross Ashton, 22, said two councillors have now assessed the house and 'were shocked'. He said: We found a dead mouse in one of the children's toy boxes and a live one in a doll's house. It is unreal. It is a dangerous health hazard. There was a rat on the two-year-old's bed and she woke up screaming. It is horrible and awful and something needs to be done about it. Rebecca just does not need this stress. Ross said rats had chewed through carpets, sofas, mattresses and flooring and toys have been thrown away as a precaution. The couple have been busy preparing the house and cleaning it for the new baby, but Ross said the rodents were making their lives hell and the children were scared to play.   Disgusting oozing toe that left specialist stunned at the amount of pus  In her Facebook post, Rebecca said council workers filled in holes with expanding foam, but the rats and mice just chewed straight through it. And she claimed the council said she couldn't be moved because the rodents were 'not a danger'. In her post Rebecca said: At my wits end honestly. I've kept it quite quiet until now but I've reached breaking point with baby due in a few weeks! Over the past few months we’ve had rats and mice in our house. We have contacted housing and it took them four weeks to even get someone out! They didn’t believe we had rats and mice together so they only laid poison. Rats and mice have to eat 60 per cent of their body weight to die from the poison. Obviously because there’s loads they just aren’t dying, and we all know how fast they breed! Council fill the holes with expanding foam and then they just chew back through it. All night we were up with chewing noises and came out onto the landing and they’re chewing through the ceiling! The council workers have said themselves they don’t see this ending. Pest control have just been into the attic and there’s not even any insulation in there.

title: housebound 84 year old man
story: NewsHousebound 84-year-old man spends three days on the floor after a fall because carers aren't allowed to pick him upHousebound and wheelchair-bound Arthur is completely reliant on care visits which have drained his le savingsShare&nbspByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer22:26, 17 SEP 2018News"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe minutes drag by in Arthur’s sterile, stale-aired, sheltered-accommodation flat – so tediously he cannot bear to look at his clock. But not as slowly as the three days he spent trapped on the floor because no carer was allowed to lt him. Arthur, 84, is housebound, wheelchair-bound and alone – and completely reliant on care visits four times a day, which have drained his le savings. That’s the proceeds of the sale of his modest &pound90,000, two-bed house, plus what he managed to save throughout his working le on the railways – and which he had hoped to leave to his two children, but which will soon be gone. In , his care is private, but council-contracted, which, at best, provides al basics and, at worst, has been shockingly neglectful and, arguably, inhumane.  In the past, bedtime visits have been missed and Arthur, who cannot use his legs and is slowly losing all use of his hands because of a stroke, was left in his wheelchair all night. Once, he spent three days on the floor after a fall, because his carers were not qualied, equipped or permitted by red tape to pick him up – and his case was not deemed a priority by the cash-strapped 999 service. “I felt completely helpless, and embarrassed,” he says. “My carers gave me a blanket, pillow, food and drink, and helped me with a urine bottle. They were placed in a very dficult situation, to be honest, they didn’t have the training or the equipment.” He explains: “Care’s on a ration, but it’s bankrupting me. I worked for 45 years, night shts, early shts, I never took a sick day. I bought my own home, I had some savings. But it’s going. “I have rips in my sweatshirt,” he adds, showing me the holes. “But I have to think twice before I buy a new one.” Arthur has about &pound20,000 left. As he now falls below the Government’s controversially designated &pound23,000 saving pot “floor”, he is receiving some contribution to his care. His sheltered flat is subsidised, too, although he still pays rent and bills. It is only when his savings hit &pound14,000 – not much to show for a letime – that his local council will be prepared to completely fund his care. This though, will rob Arthur of what he clings to – choice. It could mean a move to a cheaper care home, even outside his local area, which horries the independent-minded man.  And then, on top of these worries, there’s the excruciating loneliness. With his children living abroad, and we deceased, visitors are few and Arthur’s carers don’t hang around to chat. “It feels like I am just existing,” he says, softly. “In solitary confinement.” Arthur – not his real name – has asked us not to identy him because he feels so vulnerable. He has invited me to spend the day with him because he knows, tragically, he could be any one of tens of thousands of pensioners today suffering from the social-care crisis. Arthur moved to this accommodation more than 10 years ago when his home could not be adapted for his disability. Although there are carers on site, he is only permitted to pull his red chord for emergency “toileting”. “When I first came, there were about 10 in-house care workers, now it’s three – and only one at night,” he explains. “We used to have coffee mornings, bingo, a hair salon – that’s all stopped. There are no activities now.” Instead, Arthur’s weekly highlight is to pay &pound12 for the “ring-and-ride” to take him to a supermarket – the only one in town which will provide help.  I arrive at 7.15am for the carers’ morning visit to get Arthur out of bed, washed, dressed and fed. Today he gets a shower, but that’s just twice a week. Time drags until a half-hour visit at lunchtime, then teatime and, finally, bedtime. The two carers are polite but purely al. There’s no chit chat – I hear them refer to Arthur as “he”. “You put his deodorant on,” says one. “Have you done his hair?” To which Arthur pipes: “Yes, she’s done it.” Carers, under extreme pressure for often poor pay, don’t last long. Arthur explains: “I’ve had a stranger come to wake me up before. Some have set timers on their phones. “I would like them to be better trained, more understanding of my condition. When they move me, they accidentally hurt me. I understand they do what they can, but it’s the basics.”

title: katie hopkins end inevitable just
story: NewsopinionKatie Hopkins' end was inevitable - she was just a story, not a journalistShe paid the price in the end, says Fleet Street FoxShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist14:40, 17 SEP 2018Updated00:30, 18 SEP 2018Newsopinion"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI have long felt sorry for Katie Hopkins. She is a woman not only out of her depth, has not only floundered for more than a decade, but has no idea where she's gone wrong. It's hard to see her without thinking of a fly batting itself against a window until it expires, able to see the fresh air but unable to find it. If she reads this - which she might, because she defines herself only by what others think of her - she'll assume I'm a Left-wing liberal about to rail against her Right-wing freedom of speech. No, Katie. Someone who knows more than you is going to explain how the hatred has suffocated you. We both have epilepsy - mine very mild, hers very severe. The condition strikes in her sleep, led to her being expelled from Sandhurst, to break vertebrae and frequently dislocate her shoulders. She recently had brain surgery that ended the seizures but left her with a hole in her skull and needing to re-learn how to climb stairs. She blames the medication she has needed since young for the fact her oldest daughter is autistic and her youngest was born with a deformed hip that required many surgeries to correct. Those would be enough disability for most people to deal with. But Katie has an extra one - a mistaken belief that she's a journalist.  Let's not be precious about the Street of Shame. It is a trade, not a profession, and the only qualication necessary is a level of enthusiasm bordering on mental illness. But somewhere along the line most journalists get training. They get it from a practical degree, a vocational course, or at worst from paying attention to people who're doing it already. Katie became a journalist because first she became a media star, and she managed THAT with what she called being outspoken and everyone else called being a right cow. On The Apprentice in 2006 she hogged the camera by making amusingly-nasty remarks about maternity leave, fat people, and fellow contestants. She resigned at the end of the penultimate show citing childcare concerns, which others mocked because she had known what she was getting into. But it's perhaps worth noting both that her concerns were for two disabled daughters, and also that she was mocked mainly because she'd been so happy to mock others.  Katie sold her story for six-figure sums, had celebrity spats, and was pictured in flagrante in a field with someone else's husband. She got a regular column in her local paper the Exeter Express &amp Echo , but it ended after an online poll found 84% of the readers wanted her fired. It was a hint she did not take. She was invited onto TV as a guarantee of ratings. Three years ago Buzzfeed reported a former staffer at This Morning said she was always willing to cause controversy from the word go. Such programmes involve a chat with a producer in advance, and Katie would immediately come up with a firm line on something, and then wheeled on-air to spout it with little thought from either her or producers about where it would end. So in 2013 when she told Philip and Holly she wouldn't let her children play with someone called Tyler or Chardonnay or named after geography, it was pointed out one of her children was called India and the clip went viral.  Katie learned to make money by being rude and unapologetic, and the media learned to shore up their audience figures with a wingnut. Inevitably, she was offered a national newspaper column, a place in the Big Brother house, and more opprobrium as the hate multiplied. In 2015 she used her column to denounce migrants as cockroaches, and it quietly disappeared before she popped up at another website which racked up &pound150,000 damages plus costs for her groundless claim that a pair of Muslim brothers banned from travelling to Disneyland were linked to al Qaeda. She met holocaust deniers, tweeted about being with crew of a Save the Children ship she didn't board, and had repeated applications to join UKIP rejected. She made a habit out of getting it wrong. She moved on to LBC, left after calling for a final solution to Islamic terror, was questioned but not charged over alleged hate crimes, and more recently staged a picture with children at a school without their parents' or teachers' permission, a gross breach of journalistic ethics. She has her own website and, one hopes, has invested in some defamation legal insurance. Now she's been sued over a defamatory tweet, lost her home, and had to enter an agreement with her creditors. All of it is due to the simple fact that she attempted to be a journalist without any of the necessary skills.  If Katie had experience of working in the media before she became its favourite monster, she'd have known that what you don't say is just as important as what you do. By all means say you're snobby about the name Charmaine, but it might be an idea to know Shakespeare was happy to use it for one of his characters. If you make a habit of racking up legal bills for your employer, be careful with what you publish on social media. If you are caught lying, stop doing it. Steer clear of people with swastikas in their Twitter handles and  you don't know what defamation is, look it up. But more than anything else the lesson that Katie needed to learn was this: that becoming a hate figure is a viable but short media career. She chose a path that was an ever-decreasing spiral of bile, and it was only ever going to lead her into peril. I'm not sure she knows how she got there. She started out as entertainment, and ended up with the twin Pyrrhic victories of being praised by Donald Trump and winning an IPSO ruling against the Daily Mirror about the fact she was not detained for taking ketamine in South Africa, but for spreading racial hatred. Now she's broke and the only people still paying attention are creditors and knicker-snfing Nazis.  Katie was not a journalist but a controversialist - built and brought down by her ignorance of how journalism works. Her name is flung at others who make a much better fist of it, along with accusations they all want to be like her. Nothing could be further from the truth - journalists, above all things, want to be right. Katie was just a story, and it's a sad indictment of the media that it relied for attention on a sick woman spouting proto-fascist lies. But the principal blame is on Katie herself. She had enough clues, from as early as her first interview after leaving The Apprentice when Nick Hewer said her new brand had made you famous, but it's made you loathed. And where's it going to take you now? She never seems to have asked where it would lead. Even with training, she would never have made much of a journo. She has a thick skin and bloody-mindedness, but seems to lack empathy, accuracy, self-doubt or persuasiveness. She is a curiosity, but doesn't have any. The first rule of journalism is 'never become the story'. Not just because it's professionally embarrassing, but because all copy finishes the same way - with the word 'ends'. * Fleet Street Fox's new book, A Bluffer's Guide To Journalism, is published in March. Pre-order here.

title: madeleine mccanns dad gerry opens
story: NewsMadeleine McCann's dad Gerry opens up about mental health struggle after daughter went missing 11 years agoGerry McCann, 50, will be speaking on air about this heartache in the hope that it will help other men struggling with their mental healthShare&nbspByHana Carter13:17, 17 SEP 2018Updated14:37, 17 SEP 2018NewsGerry McCann will be appearing on Radio 4 for a special interview "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMadeleine McCann's dad will open up about his battle with depression in the years after her disappearance as part of a special show for BBC Radio 4. Gerry McCann, 50, accepted the interview to tackle the taboo surrounding men with mental health issues. The eminent cardiologist has said that he will discuss his torment in honest, personal and sometimes painful terms for the Radio 4 show. The programme is set to feature Pearl, by Simon Armitage, a modern translation of a medieval poem about a father's grief after losing his daughter. Gerry said: As a family we'd worked with Simon Armitage before, and know what a sensitive, thoughtful writer he is.  When I read the Pearl poem, I could see echoes in it with Madeleine's situation and our loss. I decided it was a good opportunity to say something about the special bond between fathers and daughters, thinking that speaking openly might help other men in similar positions. It feels like the right time. Simon Armitage said: Pearl is one of the most moving poems in the language, written by a man grieving over the loss of his young daughter. While translating it into modern English I kept thinking of the McCann family and their daughter Madeleine.  I'd written a poem for the family to mark the one thousandth day of her disappearance, spending some time with Kate and talking to her about le without Madeleine and the campaign to find her. He added: Gerry's voice hasn't been heard as much, and after reading the poem he agreed to give an extended interview, to tell his side of the story in terms of how men deal with loss and grief in a world where they're usually expected to stay strong and silent.  The couple promised never to stop looking for their little girl, who would now be 15, after her sudden disappearance sparked a worldwide search in 2007. Kate and Gerry had ed to their apartment in Algarve's Praia da Luz after having dinner in a nearby restaurant when they found her bed empty. Their twins, Sean and Amelie, who were toddlers at the time, remained in their cots. Her whereabouts still remains a mystery despite a &pound12million police investigation. They also set up a 'Find Maddie Fund' and have raised around &pound750,000 in a bid to find her.

title: meghan markle cooks serves up
story: NewsMeghan Markle serves up meals with people affected by Grenfell Tower tragedy as she launches cookbook after secret visitsMeghan Markle came up with the idea for the Together: Our Community Cookbook after making secret trips to the communityShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor10:34, 17 SEP 2018Updated10:49, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/meghan-markle-seen-cooking-new-13258748,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle can be seen cooking and serving up meals to people affected by the Grenfell Tower tragedy as she promotes a new charity cookbook. The Duchess of Sussex made several secret visits to the area before her wedding to Prince Harry, and met a group of women who came together to cook for friends, family and neighbours whose lives had been torn apart by the disaster. When she discovered they could only offer the Hubb Community Kitchen service two days a week because of funding, she suggested they released a cookbook to raise extra cash. Now the idea has become a reality, and Meghan has today released details of the book - Together: Our Community Cookbook - including a three minute video of her cooking in the kitchen with the women. She says: Together is a cookbook, but it's also the story of a west London community who gathered together in a kitchen and discovered the healing power of sharing food.  In January 2018, as I was settling into my new home in London, I met a group of women whose lives had been affected by the Grenfell fire. They had decided to get together to cook fresh food for their families and their neighbours. And so, for two days every week, these women were able to cook and share their delicious recipes together.  I'm proud to be supporting this cookbook Together. We hope you enjoy it as much as we do. The book, which is supported by The Royal Foundation and published by Penguin Random House companies,showcases over 50 recipes from women whose community was affected by the Grenfell Tower fire. In the book's foreword she writes: I immediately felt connected to this community kitchen it is a place for women to laugh, grieve, cry and cook together. Melding cultural identities under a shared roof, it creates a space to feel a sense of normalcy – in its simplest form, the universal need to connect, nurture, and commune through food, through crisis or joy – something we can all relate to…  Through this charitable endeavour, the proceeds will allow the kitchen to thrive and keep the global spirit of community alive. The duchess went to meet those affected at least twice at the beginning of the year, including a trip to the Al Manaar community mosque, which lies in the shadow of the charred shell of Grenfell Tower. She was without Prince Harry but was accompanied by a royal protection officer and one of the prince’s aides. The visits were compared to many made by her late mother-in-law Princess Diana, who often carried out charity work in secret. Speaking at the time, a leading Grenfell community member said: Meghan's visits mean so much to us. She has a special place in our hearts. A royal source added: Ms Markle has regularly been making private visits to organisations as she gets to know the charity sector.

title: mrs hinch reveals 10 best
story: NewsMrs Hinch reveals 10 of her best cleaning tips and the products she swears by - including 'Minky' the clothSophie Hinchclfe - known as Mrs Hinch - has become an online sensation after sharing videos of herself on Instagram cleaning her Essex homeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmber HicksDave Burke20:47, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/meet-mrs-hinch-whose-cleaning-13237956,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA cleaning-mad newlywed 'changing lives' with tips on how to keep your home spick and span has revealed the products everybody should have in their cupboard.  Sophie Hinchclfe , known as Mrs Hinch , has become an online sensation after filming herself cleaning her immaculate Essex home, which she shares with husband Jamie and pet pooch Henry.  Her spotless kitchen and lounge have become the envy of many and her amusing commentary as she cleans is now inspiring others to don their rubber gloves and whack out their feather dusters. People are so in awe of her vivacious personality and catchphrases - including 'All the best' - she has won a legion of fans. With 468,000 follower and counting, they call themselves Hinch Army.   Sophie even appeared on This Morning today, alongside presenters Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield, sparking even more of a cleaning frenzy.  The 28-year-old, who got married last month, admits she cleans for at least 30 minutes a day. Her pride and joy is her shiny, streak-free kitchen sink. She stores a lot of her products in a wardrobe in her garage which she calls her 'Narnia'. And she swears by certain items which she buys from shops such as Wilko, B&ampM and Poundstretcher. Some of these stores have now even dedicated shelf space with the sign 'Hinch Army' for shoppers, The hairdresser has also given all her favourite cleaning items unusual nicknames.  The one item fans will be most familiar with is 'Minkeh' which has become like gold dust and is sold out everywhere, thanks to Sophie. She uses Minkeh , Dave , Buddy , Pinkeh  and Vera . Her other top products are Flash with Febreze Bathroom Spray, CIF Stainless Steel Spray, Toilet Duck 4in1 Liquid Cleaner in the scent Fresh Pine, 1001 Carpet Spray and Zoflora. Most of the products cost &pound1 but because of Sophie's recommendations, many are selling out, or going on sale online at massively inflated prices due to the high demand.  Sophie created her profile @MrsHinchHome_X_ in March.  However, it has only been since July that the number of followers has sky rocketed since she started sharing her cleaning routines.  It just spiralled and I couldn't be more grateful, she said. It started off as around 200 or 500 [followers] a month and now it's as many as 35,000 a day. It's in the last four to six weeks that it has gone viral. I've got followers from Ireland, the US and Australia and they are all amazing. Sophie also admits cleaning has helped her cope with her anxiety. I'm a worrier, she added. For me, to keep my mind off of what was worrying me would be to clean and organise something and love the end result.  It took my mind off worrying. It helps me control my panic attacks too. Since I've started the account others have messaged me saying I've changed their lives and helped them with their mental health which to me is simply amazing. I get thousands of messages each day like this. Here are a selection of tips from her ever-growing Instagram page. 1. What to do with plugs Pour some soda crystals down each plug then use white vinegar spray then use neat disinfectant  while boiling the kettle. story: NewsMum blew £250,000 inheritance in 14 months - and now lives on the streetsLorna Webb was once flush with cash before her £600-a-day drug habit took holdShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRaymond Brown09:34, 17 SEP 2018Updated14:20, 17 SEP 2018NewsLorna Webb has revealed how her £600-a-day drug habit cost her everything "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has revealed how she blew a &pound250,000 inheritance, ended up sleeping rough and lost contact with her daughters because of her drug and alcohol addiction. Lorna Webb was married, had children and was once flush with cash, before her &pound600-a-day drug habit took hold. She has shared her heartbreaking story with the Cambridgeshire Live . Lorna clearly attempts to keep up a good appearance despite having slept outdoors in all weathers for many years. Now she struggles to eat but she once she owned two properties in Cambridge and worked in catering for many years in Wolfson College and other kitchens.  Several years ago - Lorna can't quite remember - she inherited &pound250,000 from her family. This was to be spent on drugs - and Lorna's innate generosity and kindness meant that she spent a lot of her inheritance on other struggling addicts.  She once was flush with cash and was spending almost &pound18,000 a month on drugs or &pound600 a day. Lorna now had the inheritance and started to spend. She said: When I got the money I was living locally, staying round friends and everything. My mates are all addicts so there was no way that I was going to leave them without. If I could have balanced it a bit more I would have done something with it. I am glad the money went to the area. The dollar has got invested. I don't mean any disrespect to my family. I lost a lot of weight and had a nervous breakdown. The heroin stopped me eating. It's very painful when you put weight back on your body and then you lose it. When you have a nervous breakdown it is very painful to your body. Lorna said she then attempted to rent a home in Cambridge but even with a small fortune in the bank she said no-one would let a property to her.  She said: I am an addict myself and I was dossing around dferent places. I tried to get a place but they weren't having none of it. That's what I don't understand. I had local connections and I was trying to rent a place. I had money to buy. I would have got a boat. Somebody must have been using my ID, plus the fact that I am adopted which doesn't help. Lorna spent most of her inheritance on feeding her habit and giving money away to addicts. She has little to show for it now and lives a hand-to-mouth existence. And in a heartbreaking moment, Lorna admitted her regret in not giving more of the money to her daughters and how she longs to see them again. The day before she spoke to Cambridgeshire Live she thought her daughter had driven past the spot in Mill Road where Lorna can be found on most days. She said: I guess I bought a few little bits and pieces - some jewellery. I bought both my girls some school kits. I love my girls. I have heard that they are doing really well. I hope so. I haven't seen them. I don't know  that was my daughter that I waved to the other day. I am not sure where they are. I would just like to see that they are safe. Sasha will be coming up to her mid-twenties and Faith eight years behind. They are both firing on all cylinders. They have all their pistons.  Lorna spoke of her le on the street and the camaraderie she felt with other rough sleepers. And she told of how many of her pals had been lost to drugs and violence. She said: It's not too bad on the street. We have a good crew around and we all look out for each other. Everyone has their own situation but no one will let anyone down. We've all got each others backs here. We've just lost some friends recently, but there's no way anyone is going to go unnoticed. No chance. That's not happening. Lorna also knew Peter Anderson, also known as Blue, who died from multiple stab wounds after being attacked on Stourbridge Common on July 25. Two London men have been charged with murder. Lorna said Blue was a gentle man and was shocked when she learned he had died. She added: I knew Blue. It is surreal to me like it hasn't happened. It's just surreal. I don't get it. And she spoke of the trouble in Mill Road and how traders wanted to clean up the area. She said: I score here but I've not noticed much trouble. It's probably other people getting involved and other people coming down here  the truth be known. I know people locally and there are things that they go through. But I think it's other people getting involved. Asked  she would have done things dferently, she said: I had wanted to bless my children. I wanted something for them. Lorna has been through the courts over the years. In March 2012 armed police were called in after Lorna was seen carrying a kne by an ambulance crew. She was jailed for eight months after Cambridge Crown Court heard she had armed herself for protection before a confrontation with another woman.

title: woman who said no boys
story: NewsWoman who said "no boys liked her at school" completely transforms after losing 6st and dropping 5 dress sizesKaty Parry, 25, used to tuck into Chinese takeaways for lunch up to five times a week and weighed 18 stone at her heaviestShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAnna Riley17:33, 17 SEP 2018Updated19:13, 17 SEP 2018NewsKate Parry, 25, went down five dress sizes and lost six stone "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman has given herself a complete image overhaul after she was called 'fat' and said no boys liked her at school.  Kate Parry dropped five dress sizes and lost six stone over the past five years.  And she has gone from having no interest in exercising, to becoming a fitness fanatic keen on helping others achieve their goals.  The 25-year-old used to eat Chinese takeaway for lunch four or five times a week and at her heaviest, weighed 18 stone. She blamed her huge weight gain on a combination of laziness, poor diet and long nights on the computer playing The Sims and talking to friends on MSN.  Speaking to Hull Live , she said: My school was close to a Chinese take away, so we would go there most days for lunch which wasn’t ideal.   At first I wasn’t bothered about my weight but all my friends at school had boyfriends and I never had one, no boys were ever interested in me. Going out with her friends became uncomfortable as Kate started comparing herself to others, and leaving school only made her more conscious of her weight. Being called fat and made things worse and Kate’s self-confidence plummeted. Something had to give and she eventually mustered the motivation to go to the gym and joined Xercise4Less. Honestly, I think it was me who motivated myself, I had it in my head that I wanted to lose weight and feel good about myself and once you see results from all the hard work it makes you even more motivated to achieve more, said Miss Parry. Using a personal trainer for six months was a huge help as Kate learned about the benefits of weight training to achieve her goals. Now, she trains four to five times a week depending on her schedule.  Kate’s diet needed to change along with her exercise habits, and she ditched the Chinese food and late-night chocolate for more substantial foods. Now I usually eat porridge for breakfast, tuna, rice and vegetables for lunch and then dinner usually consists of Quorn with potatoes and vegetables. said Miss Parry. Discipline with her diet and training regime is key for Kate, but she is adamant that numbers on the scale are not important. I don’t weigh myself anymore, I don’t believe that the number on the scale represents anything at all, said Miss Parry. It’s just a number and in the past I’ve got to a point where I became obsessed with weighing myself and it made me unhappy. I go by how I feel and how my clothes fit but last time I got weighed I was around 12 stone.

title: coca cola looking producing drinks
story: NewsCoca-Cola 'looking at producing drinks with marijuana in' as companies rush to test drug-infused marketThe huge soft drink company is closely watching the fast-growing marijuana drinks market for a possible entry in the near futureShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter22:37, 17 SEP 2018Updated22:38, 17 SEP 2018NewsCould cannabis-infused Coca-Cola soon be on the shelves? "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Coca-Cola is in 'serious talks' to produce marijuana-infused drinks, according to reports in the United States.  The huge soft drink company is closely watching the fast-growing marijuana drinks market for a possible entry that would expand the world’s largest soft drink maker’s ambitions further away from sugary sodas. Coca-Cola announced its interest in a statement on Monday, responding to a report from BNN Bloomberg that said it was in talks with Canada’s Aurora Cannabis Inc to develop drinks infused with cannabidiol , the non-psychoactive chemical found in marijuana. Coke would join a rush by major alcohol makers and a cigarette company to test the cannabis market and find partners ahead of the October 17 launch of legal recreational marijuana in Canada.  Coke and Aurora, in separate statements, each said they were interested in cannabidiol-infused beverages but would not comment on any specics or talks. Aurora’s stock soared 17 percent, while Coke’s edged up slightly. The CBD drinks would likely aim to ease inflammation, pain and cramping, the BNN report said. Wells Fargo analyst Bonnie Herzog called the news “an exciting potential development” as it would take Coke into another fast-growing healthier segment following last month’s 5.1 billion deal for Costa Coffee and expand cannabis-infused drinks in the area of al wellness products. The CBD products likely would be dferent from those produced by alcohol makers, which would likely give drinkers a buzz from tetrahydrocannabinol , the main psychoactive chemical in marijuana.  Beer makers Constellation Brands, Molson Coors and Heineken are all playing in the market for cannabis products. For example, Heineken’s craft beer Lagunitas recently launched Hi-Fi Hops, a beer-flavored sparkling water with THC and CBD. “The THC beverages probably sit better with the beer makers, and maybe CBD fits better with Coke, in terms of playing off the health trend,” said Liberum analyst Nico von Stackelberg. Canada is the first major economy to legalize recreational marijuana, and shares in cannabis producers have rallied in anticipation. New Cannabis Ventures' global cannabis stock index has risen about 87 per cent over the past year. Several US states have legalized marijuana but it remains against federal law. Cannabis' legal status is being reviewed by the UK government - so what does this actually mean? Currently, cannabis is a Class B drug and that is not going to change. That means possession will still carry an unlimited fine and up to five years' jail - rising to 14 years for dealers. And recreational use will be illegal. But the 'schedule', which sets out how a drug can be used for medical purposes, is now being reviewed by the Home Office. Currently, cannabis is Schedule 1 - meaning it has 'no therapeutic value' in the eyes of the law. If a medical benefit is identied, that schedule will change, meaning you could get it on prescription. This would likely only apply to certain forms like cannabis oil, rather than leaves that can be smoked. Separately, there is already a system where patients can get a 'licence' to use cannabis, even though it's against the law. This is very rare but has happened in the cases of epileptic boys Alfie Dingley and Billy Caldwell. This licensing system is also being overhauled, with a new panel of medical experts set up to advise the Home Office on future cases.

story: NewsHurricane Florence: Boy, one, found dead in North Carolina floodwater after losing grip of desperate mumThe death toll from the extreme weather - which has been downgraded to a tropical depression - has risen to 18 with flood water cutting off a city of more than 100,00 peopleShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter16:51, 17 SEP 2018Updated17:00, 17 SEP 2018NewsKaiden Lee-Welch lost grip of his mum as they both battled in flood water"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A one-year-old boy has become the latest victim of Hurricane Florence in the United States, taking the death toll to 18.  Rescue workers near Charlotte, North Carolina recovered the body of Kaiden Lee-Welch who had slipped out of his mother’s hands after their car got stuck in floodwater on Sunday evening.  Rescue teams searched overnight for the boy after rushing water pushed his mother's car off the road, the Union County Sherf's Office said on Facebook .  The mother had driven around barricades on a closed stretch of road, the post said. Police wrote: The mother... continued traveling east until her vehicle encountered rushing water flowing across the road.  Her vehicle left the roadway and came to rest amongst a group of trees.  She managed to free herself and Kaiden, who was in a car seat, but lost her grip on him in the rushing water.  The city of Wilmington, with roughly 119,000 residents, has been cut off with most routes to it submerged in floodwater. Evacuation orders are still being issued as rivers rise and dams are tested. The authorities in Hoke County, west of Fayetteville, told residents late Sunday to flee “due to the possible breach of the dam, reports the New York Times. At least 18 people have died in storm-related incidents, including a man and a woman in Horry County, S.C. who died from carbon monoxide poisoning.  Isolated tornadoes were also a threat on Monday, and forecasters issued about two dozen tornado warnings in North Carolina before 8am local time.  Florence was a tropical depression on Monday with maximum sustained winds of 30 mph  as it headed through Virginia  and toward New England.  With the rain and winds headed north, some residents in North and South Carolina started to  to their homes as the sun peeked through the clouds briefly for the first time in days. Tens of thousands of houses have been damaged, but for many parts of the Carolinas, the worst is yet to come as river levels rise to historic levels, said Zach Taylor, a meteorologist with the U.S. National Weather Service.

story: NewsMalaysia Airlines Flight MH17: Russia claims it was really Ukraine who shot down jet over war zoneThe Buk missile was built near Moscow and delivered to a Ukrainian military unit in 1986, Russia's defence ministry claimsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching10:44, 17 SEP 2018Updated11:07, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/malaysian-airlines-flight-mh17-downed-8932316,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRussia has sensationally claimed Ukraine shot down Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, saying it didn't have the missile that brought down the doomed jet. The Buk missile was built at a plant near Moscow during the Cold War and delivered to Ukraine in 1986 when it was a Soviet republic, the Kremlin claims. A team of international investigators has pointed the blame at Moscow, saying videos and other evidence show a missile launcher being secretly transported into territory held by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The investigators claim a Russian-made Buk missile brought down the jet and the launcher used in the air disaster - which killed all 298 passengers and crew onboard - belonged to Russia's military.  But Russia's Ministry of Defence claims those videos have been manipulated, and denies claims that Moscow was involved in the July 2014 tragedy of the flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur. At a news conference on Monday, Russia's military provided an audio recording which it claims is proof that Ukraine was involved in the air disaster. It claims that the missile used to bring down the jet was no longer in its hands.  Russian officials claim serial numbers found on missile fragments show the weapon was built in 1986 and it was owned by Ukraine when the jet was shot down. General Nikolay Parshin told reporters that the missile was sent to Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic military unit 20152, which is now the 223rd anti-aircraft defence regiment of Ukraine's armed forces. The general claims that unit was involved in Ukraine's offensive against Russian-backed separatists in the Donetsk region in June 2014, just weeks before the airliner was shot down.  In May, the international team of investigators, led by the Netherlands, said Russia's armed forces supplied the missile launcher that fired a Russian-made Buk missile at MH17 over the war zone. Wilbert Paulissen, head of the Netherlands' national police crime squad, said the missile was fired from Russia's 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade. Moscow is not involved in that investigation, and claims the probe is biased.

title: dundee families in shock after popular support scheme closes due to lack of funds
story: Families have been left shocked after a popular support scheme announced it was closing due to a lack of funds.The Child and Family Project based in Chalmers Ardler Church revealed it would close next month as it could no longer fund a project leader.The group has been in operation for 27 years and used a range of grants to support the leader’s £24,000 a year salary, but will now close on October 5 as it no longer has the moneys to continue.Dad-of-four Tarig Brady, 33, whose twin daughters attended one of the group’s services, said he had no idea it was struggling with funding.He said: “It is a major shock and it is definitely going to be a big loss to the community. Parents come from all over Dundee to use this service.“I have four kids so I’m here almost every day and it gives parents a bit of a respite.“The playgroup not being here anymore is going to have a massive impact on my le.”Mum Anna Goszczynska, 37,  takes her 11-year-old daughter and nine-year-old son to the group every week.She said: “It is a huge loss to the community. We’ve been going to the group for four years. We came in this week and someone said there was no more money to keep running.“It is such a happy group with lots of grandparents going with kids. I hope something can be done.”After retiring from the scheme in 2016, former project leader Christine Black said: “Funding has always been a problem and it is a really sad situation.“It is an enormous loss because the group gives people friendships, a leline and parenting skills.”Trustee Renee Fordes said: “We have had to close because the project leader has handed in her notice and there are no funds to provide another salary. We have a new minister coming in place who might have ideas.”

title: dundee united new boy booth says he shouldnt have tried to run off injury
story: Callum Booth admits had he been a Dundee United veteran instead of a rookie, two months into the season Arabs would have seen a lot more of him than they have.The 27-year-old is ready for today’s Championship clash with Morton at Tannadice and,  he completes the 90 minutes, it will be the first time since his debut in mid-July.That’s when he damaged ankle ligaments in the Betfred Cup defeat at Ross County, an injury suffered early on in the tie.It could have forced him off immediately but the fact he played on was, he admits, a mistake on his part that was caused by him being new to the team.“Firstly, it’s been good to be back, obviously being out for five weeks was a long time,” said the former Partick Thistle defender.“It felt like ages, especially when you join a new club because you just want to make good impressions and get games under your belt right away.“It was my ankle, I did in it in the first half at Ross County and quite stupidly played on.“The physio came on, had a look and I thought I could probably run it off. I did feel it for the rest of the game but being at a new club you just want to show up well in your first game.“If I’d been here a couple of years I would have come off but, because it was my first game, I stayed on and probably made it worse – I woke up the next day and it was agony.“The result was five weeks out and that wasn’t ideal but it’s in the past now and I’m raring to go.”What he isn’t doing is expecting to walk right back into the team and he knows, in the shape of fellow left-back Jamie Robson, he’s facing strong competition for that defensive berth.“Jamie has been doing really well, he’s a good player and it’s good to have competition. There are a few boys still out and they’re coming back, so there’s going to be even more and that can only be good for the squad.“I feel that, when we have everyone fit, we have a very strong squad and it’s just going to be a case of getting everyone fit and keeping it that way. There are always injuries, though, it’s part and parcel of football.”His mission now is to help however he can as United look to keep picking up points to mount a strong promotion challenge.The aim today is to pick up three points. He knows that will not be easy against a Morton side who will be something of an unknown quantity after their recent change of manager.It saw ex-United boss Ray McKinnon quit after just three months in chare to take over at Falkirk and former Rangers star Jonatan Johansson replace him.“Any team that gets a new manager, they usually take a couple of weeks to implement what the new man is trying to do. This is Johansson’s first game in charge so we are not really too sure how they’ll set up.“One thing we know is they have good inidual players and experience in there as well in the middle of the park.“It’s going to be a tough game and they are a good side. They’ve had a good couple of seasons where they’ve always been in or close to the play-offs and done well in a few cups.”For United the aim is to build on a three-game unbeaten run that’s seen seven points taken from the last nine, though Booth believes it should have been a full house.“We are going not too bad but,  we want to be winning the league, we have to be holding on to results like the one we should have had at Alloa last time out.“We didn’t play great but 1-0 going into the last 10 minutes, we should have seen the game out. Still, seven points from the last nine after a tricky start to the season is not too bad.”

title: ray mckinnon dundee tried to punt ex captain darren odea to falkirk
story: New Falkirk manager Ray McKinnon has revealed the deadline day madness at the Championship strugglers – and even had a Dundee defender offered to him with just minutes to go till the window slammed shut.The former Dundee United boss was only in the door for a few hours after his shock switch from Greenock Morton.McKinnon managed to seal a deal for Rangers striker Zak Rudden on loan but narrowly missed out on former Tannadice loanee Anthony Ralston.He also revealed Dundee boss Neil McCann offered the services of former skipper Darren O’Dea as the clock ticked towards midnight.McKinnon said: “We had Darren O’Dea getting punted to us at 10.30 at night by Neil McCann. I was in the house!“We were trying to do a couple of things late at night. We were close, but we got Rudden, that was brilliant.“It was so late, we were trying to settle with players at 10 at night. It was mad.”Thirty-one-year-old O’Dea has been frozen out at Dens this season and is yet to make an appearance despite being fit.

title: tannadice visit from jack 95 thought to be dundee uniteds oldest living player
story: The man who is believed to be the Dundee United&#8217s oldest living former player will be in attendance for the Championship clash against Morton on Tannadice on Saturday.Jack Butchart, who celebrated his 95th birthday this week, will be there as a boardroom guest of fans’ group ArabTRUST.He had a brief spell in the Tannadice squad in the mid-1940s.Jack’s family had strong United connections before that and his father Joseph was club secretary during its formative years as Dundee Hibernian.This afternoon Arabs had the chance to get up close and personal with two of the team when Frederic Frans and Yannick Loemba visited the club shop at Tannadice.Congolese winger Loemba has become a big favourite with the support because of his displays and posing with fans for selfies.

title: today you can help set a world record with the beano at dundee waterfront
story: Members of the public are being invited to take part in a world record attempt – while celebrating the opening of V&ampA Dundee.The Beano will have its very own “den” at Slessor Gardens today as part of 3D Festival.A host of local music acts are set to perform at the event, but there will also be a range of activities on offer for families and children.And the iconic comic is leading the way with its official Guinness World Record attempt to create the largest “finish the comic strip” competition ever.A special edition of The Beano has been created to mark the occasion.In it, Dennis and friends meet cartoon versions of Philip Long, director of V&ampA Dundee, and Kengo Kuma, the Japanese architect who designed the building.There are nods to Dundee’s sporting heritage – as the V&ampA is coloured tangerine and black, and blue and white, by the mischievous characters, in reference to the colours worn by Dundee United and Dundee.A version of Dennis from the 1950s, The McManus and the Star Wars-themed video of the V&ampA which came out last year, also all feature.The final cell of the comic strip is left blank and children can draw an item that they want to feature in the V&ampA.All the pictures will be collected as part of the world record bid.Mr Long will then choose a winner, which will go on display in the V&ampA.

title: va dundee all you need to know about todays 3d festival as local acts take centre stage
story: A series of Dundee musicians will herald the opening of the V&ampA today.The museum finally opens its doors to the public, with lucky ticket-holders given their first glimpse of the £80 million attraction. Across the road, in Slessor Gardens, celebrations to mark the opening continue with the second day of the 3D Festival.The event will feature a host of on-stage performances and a number of family activities.Things kick off at 11am as musician SHHE – otherwise known as Su Shaw or Panda Su – takes to the stage.She said: “Dundee is special – it doesn’t show off in ways that other cities do – so maybe in the past you had to work harder to find that out.“I’m excited to be joining some incredible local artists on-stage to celebrate its opening.”Keeping the music going from 11.50am will be Kashmir Crows, a six-piece based in the city.The group – who have been likened to bands such as Arcade Fire and Black Keys – play a mix of alternative rock, indie, soul, blues and funk, and are a familiar act on the local music scene.Lead singer Ian Black, from Lochee, said: “We pride ourselves on being a Dundonian band and to be a part of the biggest cultural event in Dundee for generations, we’re totally over the moon. We’ve been rehearsing and have just played at the Glenfiddich Festival Experiment so we’re on a roll. We can’t wait to play for everyone.”Dundee two-piece St Martiins are next up, performing a set at 12.40pm. Featuring Katie Lynch and Mark Johnston, they claim to have crafted a “unique sound” through music “laced with dark tones”.Katie said: “The V&ampA is bringing something new to the creative scene here in Dundee, which has been needing a good refresh. We’re extremely lucky as a band and I want to see more people get the chance to get involved in the music business. Today’s going to be great – we’re so happy that we were asked.”At 1.30pm is Andrew Wasylyk, the alias of Dundee writer and producer Andrew Mitchell.He describes his work as being “cinematic nostalgia” with “elements of Baroque pop and the influence of classic 1970s songwriters”. Andrew said: “It’s a privilege to be involved and to play a small part in the opening of this new chapter for the city. I’m a fan of Kengo Kuma’s architecture and I’m excited to see the V&ampA evolve and grow with the local communities. I’m really looking forward to performing with a nine-piece ensemble.”Kyle Falconer  – frontman of The View – is the most familiar name on the bill and he will appear on-stage at 2.30pm. The Dryburgh lad has been on tour promoting his debut solo album No Thank You of late, and is expected to perform hits from that LP along with a few well-known tunes from the band that made him famous.Another familiar face appears at 3.30pm in Be Charlotte  – the stage name of local singer Charlotte Brimner.She continues to make a name for herself, having signed a record deal earlier this year and performed last night before Primal Scream on the first day of the 3D Festival.Rounding the day off will be Danny Wilson icon Gary Clark, who’ll play a solo set to his hometown from 4.30pm before being joined by Sistema – the children’s schools orchestra – at 4.50pm to bring the festival to a close. Gary found fame with hits like Mary’s Prayer – which is expected to get an outing today.Organisers say the festival is all-standing and entry is via two gates on Thomson Avenue.Those attending aren’t allowed to take food or drink but outlets will be available.There will be a host of other activities taking place at Slessor Gardens, including a special event involving The Beano – where children can complete a comic cell in an attempt to break a world record.

title: va dundee huge queue as museum opens to wider public after debut weekend
story: A large queue of eager visitors has formed as people aim to get their first glimpse of the V&ampA Dundee.After a weekend of celebrations and exclusive access to lucky ballot winners, the museum opened its doors to the general public.The iconic building officially opened at 10am today.&mdash Mary&#39sChapelProject  September 17, 2018Shortly after the opening time, a large queue had formed &#8211 stretching past the RRS Discovery.The iconic £80 million museum welcomed thousands of visitors over Saturday and Sunday. Among those were city celebrities Brian Cox and Lorraine Kelly.It features a number of free exhibits as well as the featured Ocean Liners: Speed and Style, which requires the purchase of a ticket..Mr Cox said: “I think we all agree, those of us who are close to the city and who are close to what is going on here, it’s a very emotional experience.Great to see people wandering around outside the museum already 🤗We open at 10.00 everyone&#39s welcome. Let&#39s do this. pic.twitter/qegZnWzJdq&mdash V&ampA Dundee  September 17, 2018“Especially for me, I’ve known the city for many years, I was born here, went to school here and had my first theatre roles here, so to  and see what’s happening now – it’s transformed the city.“It will attract industry and it will attract tourists, it’s the beginning of hopefully a paradigm sht in Dundee and it will put Dundee on the map for the first time.“It’s an amazing experience. Where it’s situated on the Tay and what Kengo Kuma has done in terms of design – I believe he has said it is his best work.”Mr Cox said he believed Dundee will come to be defined by the museum and having been involved with the project from an early stage, he promised to attend the opening.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon also attended and even paid a brief visit to the 3D Festival over the road on Friday night appearing for selfies.
